reviewText:
I finished this game, so I feel like i can give it a review. I was a big fan of The Neverhood and Skullmonkeys. I was hyped when Tennapel said about the movie, then I heard about Neverhood sequel and I was hyped even more. Even helped to kickstart the game. But today, when I finally managed to play it i was...dissapointed.
The story is just dull, the world isnt shown at all, unlike in the neverhood. You see some rooms, some creatures pop sometimes, but it just feels forced and like the creators were just putting stuff into the game so it would not feel empty. The main antagonist is dull, his story, motives and transformation are not explained. Cant even dare to compare him to Klogg.
Also, given the time and money, it should be longer. Feels like I just finished the episode 1 of the 6 part series, like Wolf Among Us or The Walking Dead.
I really expected something greater and better storywise. In previous games I loved the world, its humour and sadism. There is almost none. If I wasnt The Neverhood fan, I would have never bought or played Armikrog.

So... This game isn't a Neverhood sequel. It's Not even close to Neverhood but I will judge this game on its own, but I will compare it to it.
And I wont lie, I did buy it in hope of a sequel in the spirit of The Neverhood. Lets do this quick.
I did finish this game, twice. And I'm Really done with the game.
Now I'm gona sum up the game:

Animation:
-gameplay: 9/10
-Cutscene: 9/10
-End Cutscene: 5/10

Story: Its completely fine. It got the humor of Doug Tennaple(who worked on The Neverhood and Earthworm Jim). I think it falls flat in some places.

Voice acting: Great. Huge fan of Rob Paulsen(voice of Pinky, Yakko Warner, 2 of the turtles of TMNT and Spike from Land Before Time)

Puzzles: This is where I'm really sad to say. Alot of it are too easy, some is confusing.

AND THE MUSIC: F**K, S**T, F**K. Im so disapointed, BUT the music in this game fits this game.
If anyone Remember The Neverhood, You know the music was memorible, also those small jingles. In this game It was REALLY disapointing.
Theres a video out of Terry S. Taylor playing a song that was for this game. its called Boo hoo Hah". Its just like The Neverhood. And Its amazing. I WANT THAT SOUNDTRACK.

Final thoughts: Short game. Fantastic Animation. Great voice acting. Okey Music. MEhdiocer music

reviewText:
I pledged for this game back when they did their kickstarter. A big fan of Dougs work on Earth Worm Jim and calling this the spiritual successor of the Neverhood I couldn't say no to this.

I will get the pros out of the way first. Animation and voice acting is stunning. The visuals pop and you can see that charm we have grown to love.

The backstory is amazing. If you read the hall of records and learn the tale of Armikrog its an amazing story.

It made me feel like I was back in the computer shop playing my childhood all over again.

But as for the negatives. The main characters do feel like they are out of place in a story that is so much grander. Its almost as if they dont connect too well. The back story is well versed but when trying to play the game you feel its overshaddowed by characters that dont belong.

I love the writing dont get me wrong its amazing. But when Klayman was a part of the Neverhood he was a part of the story. Here it just feels like a side note to a grand story.

The game even though Ive heard is the same length in screens seems way shorter. I beat it in two days over an hour a day. And the ending is clear they want to continue with the story but Im not invested in Tommynaught as a character.

The puzzles are repeated alot. The Neverhood mixes them up. Having not just button pushing or slide puzzles but puzzles that have a different look and feel to them. Some may operate the same but they physical appearance changes which keeps it fresh. Here it just felt filled in.

Some of the assets seem repeated besides the puzzles. In particular stretching a character to make him seem taller instead of making a new one seemed cheap. Same with mixing cartoon eggs with animated ones. The styles clashed alot.

The soundtrack was something I was looking forward to the most but the game decided that instead of theming rooms with songs that it would just pick and choose what to play. Id like to think this is a glitch. Because I dont know what the hell they are going to put on the soundtrack. Honestly each rooms music made it. Here it doesnt even function.

There was a lot less cutscenes. Even quirky ones that made the Neverhood fun to play. The ones that just stick out and dont mean anything but are just plain funny to watch. Even in SkullMonkeys they had that down easy!

And last. The glitches are so high! From my save file being erased. Passing through doors I shouldnt. Clicking something that doesnt work only to leave or move slighty to the right and clicking it again until it does. Crashing the game and seeing the hotspots not even mash with the mouse. The Unity engine almost seems like a last thought in making this work.

To delay the game an extra month makes me wonder what they did. Not in a rude way but Id like to know what went wrong. The bug testing team didnt do a damn thing. And the other night someone from the team said there wasnt too many issues and they were happy with it.

I can accept everything else. If it wasnt for the glitches. A month is enough time to fine tune it. There should be no issue.
Again I love the game itself and can ignore the rest if it wasnt for that. But this falls short of The Neverhood and trying to recapture it. And does make you want to come back for more. But the question is....will they make things right if they decide to continue the story?

I hope that my kickstarter gear is amazing as they said because it breaks my heart to say that I feel a bit let down.

reviewText:
Warning: contains spoilers.
Review version: 1.01 (updated)

I cannot help but compare this game to “The Neverhood”, since it was advertised as a spiritual successor to it and I don’t think it’s wrong in any way.

Pros:
• Some parts of the game are made of clay, which is a rare thing.
• Nice overall design, somehow rich visuals.
• Made me replay and realize the beauty of ”The Neverhood” for the third time.

Cons:
• Lots of technical issues revolving around:
1) localization (some of them fixed as of 1.01, but you still cannot choose the language via options menu or launch parameter / config), 2) subtitles, 3) cursor, 4) controls, 5) sound, 6) music, 7) transparency masks.
• Lacks polish and feels like an unfinished low-cost product, which is unacceptable for an adventure game which lacks branching plot and has almost none to zero replay value.
• Easy, boring, uninspired puzzles, some of them are recycled three times.
• Not heavy, but noticeable recycling of the assets.
• Inconsistent background resolution.
• Inconsistent use of clay, there is clay animated in PS.
• Not enough quality claymation sequences.
• “The Neverhood”s humor is not included.
• The story is dull, has no closure. Ending sequence is so ugly, it’s cringewothy.
• Generic music which hardly creates any mood. Truly disappointing work, Mr. Terry S Taylor. No lossless OST in the Deluxe package, low-bitrate MP3s only: http://i.imgur.com/yCRdoXu.png.
• The resolution of the assets could have been higher, last time I checked it was 2015.
• Protagonist’s sidekick exists purely for gameplay purposes, there is no smart or funny dialogues between him and the protagonist.

Even though the game has no game-breaking bugs and could be played through, the release version still feels like a deep beta, looks like the QA was either non-existent or made by deaf and blind people.
If you’d like to see some of the rough spots, check this album: https://imgur.com/a/yDUTl (updated with some other screenshots I took during the playthrough)
I counted the total amount of unique screens in “The Neverhood” and even though it’s roughly the same as in the “Armikrog”,  “The Neverhood” was a small interconnected world made of clay, “Armikrog” is just a bunch of screens.
If you would like to see for yourself, check out the screens of “The Neverhood”, here you go, all of them: https://imgur.com/25FGTd2
Most of the Armikrog’s screens, compressed by Steam: https://imgur.com/a/S5BqH

Verdict: spiritless successor of “The Neverhood”, the world would have been better without it.

reviewText:
I just had a lengthy debate with myself over whether or not I could recommend this game. Ultimately,  I can not.

I grew up in the heart of the adventure game era. I am very forgiving of the pitfalls of most adventure games as long as I feel like I had fun at the end of the day. As a fan of Neverhood, Earthworm Jim, and adventure gaming in general, I was quite excited when this popped up on Kickstarter. I dropped WAY more cash than normal to get art books, signed prints from Doug, and other swag.

I've learned to temper my expectations from kickstarter, I've also learned to not expect these games for several years and even then, not to play them when they are first released. I picked up Armikrog the day after a patch which added context sensitive cursors, and several other minor fixes.

Right off the bat I was thrown into a static menu screen. I immediately missed the lively, animated title screen from Neverhood that set the tone for he rest of the game.  Unfortunately, this static screen was setting the tone for this game as well.

A majority of the game is played across sparse rooms. Some are simply a few walls made of clay with a couple fingernail lines drawn into them. Others have gorgeous set pieces using found objects. But even the gorgeous scenes typically revolved around a single item. In the intro we get a glimpse of this planet, it's wildlife, the slapstick style 'klayman' humor we loved in Neverhood, and a glimpse at the relationship between Tommynaut and Beak Beak. And then the game starts and we might as well throw all that out the window. It becomes painfully obvious that after the intro, the minds who developed Neverhood stepped out and the clay jockeys stepped in.

The game itself takes place fully inside a fortress. So the organic puzzles that inhabited Neverhood are nowhere to be found. The fortress itself is composes of 3 towers (4 technically, but the final one is *very* limited).

Each tower has the exact same setup. Get the main door open, get the power on, get some more doors open, move to the next tower. Even the puzzle types repeat themselves, almost always relying on find a symbol somewhere else and type it in here".

One puzzle in particular has a baby crying until you solve it. The puzzle itself happens to be an audio puzzle. It requires careful listening and patience. After several minutes of having a baby cry over your the sounds of the puzzle and then having to sit there while the tune plays to verify you got the puzzle right.... well

reviewText:
The Neverhood is one of my all time favorite games, so I've been hyped all year for this.
What a disappointment. Not only is it riddled with game breaking bugs, but a good chunk of the game is recycled content. Furthermore, it's full of general design problems that I just can't forgive. Ones that The Neverhood didn't have.

It often falls into the 'Why doesn't anything react to my actions' adventure game pitfall. This is mainly because you're controlling both Tommynaut and Beakbeak. For example, buttons that Tommynaut should realistically be able to press can only be pressed by Beakbeak. The problem stems from the fact that there's no negative feedback on elements like that. Clicking on something you can't use under that context just doesn't get a response, so you can't be sure if an object can be interacted with, or if it's a background object only. This becomes even more apparent when you're making a point and click game in an alien setting where puzzle elements aren't conventional things. This is where a tough brain teaser turns into a test of persistence. In my opinion, you should never have to brute force a puzzle because you don't even know what the components of the puzzle are.

The menus are unresponsive as hell. Again, an example of the lack of conveyance this game has in general. Turns out the game sometimes doesn't save over files properly. It has an autosave feature, but that's worthless if you load a file that isn't actually the one you wanted, since the game just autosaves immediately. Hitboxes on a lot of clickable things are rather finicky. It seems to improve as the game progresses, but holy moly is the first section a mess of bad hit detection. Basically it's all problems that should've evolved out of the point and click genre by now.

I have to cut it some slack on account of how well it is presented outside of the game design, however. It looks just like I'd want a 1080p Neverhood to look. The setting is interesting. I'm a little bummed that the FMV parts aren't in 1080p too though. The music is great when it actually plays. The audio often doesn't seem to trigger properly, including character dialogue. Terry S Taylor's music in this game is a lot more ambient this time around, which really fits the desolate and spooky kind of setting that the Armikrog fortress has.

Bugs and buyer's remorse aside, I'd give this game an average out of ten. To anyone who is a fan of puzzle games and point and click adventures, click away from this one (hur hurr) and save your money. It's most likely not what you're looking for. Now excuse me while I go hang myself.

reviewText:
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase
3) Recommended purchase during a sale4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

Feet of clay
From the creator of the wildly successful Earthworm Jim series and the spiritual successor to cult point and click adventure The Neverhood that saw moderate success in the late nineties thanks to the fact that it was an entire game modeled out of clay. This unique selling hook was the reason that The Neverhood was able to stand out from the crowd back in the day in an adventure game genre that had slowly devolved into terrible full motion video (FMV) games staring z-grade actors that saw the gaming industry try and compete with Hollywood and fail miserably. It also arrived during the sundown of the golden age of adventure gaming as the genre slowly lost ground to new the kid on the block - the 3D first person shooter. Naturally my interest was piqued upon hearing about Armikrog even though the creator, Doug TenNabel, would go on to utter some distrubing bigotry that left many fans the world over reeling in shock and refusing to support anymore of his work. While I don't agree with the remarks he passed at all, personally - I don't put much stock in the ramblings of a fool on the wrong side of history.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=534285674
Having now fully completed Armikrog what amazes me the most is that the game feels like it was something made at gunpoint. It's almost as if everyone involved didn't really want to be involved or they either lost interest rather quickly after becoming involved. While the claymation modeled environments are utterly gorgeous to look at, you soon start to realize as time marches on that what the game is missing the most is a heart and rather importantly a soul. It is almost as if the life has been sapped right out of Armikrog leaving nothing behind but a husk of reused puzzles that honestly seem like they required very little thought to put together. I can't imagine kickstarter backers being terribly impressed with what they got for their investment because despite the pedigree and talent behind Armikrog it appears they were referencing the manual Game Development for Dummies.

The game was even repeatedly delayed, much to the ire of the fans, but based on what is in the final offer it honestly feels like 1/3 of the game got developed while the remainder was abandoned in favor of reuse. Now I know that constructing an entire game out of clay is no small feat and possibly incredibly time consuming (I am not sure I have never tried it) but that does not excuse a collection of puzzles that get reused in four different locations. Once the player has advanced past the first gate Armikrog looses all its appeal as the remaining three are just different flavors of the same set of puzzles. Even if this game had somehow gotten publisher funding back in the late nineties it would have still been a pale imitation of what the genre was offering at the time.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=534503683
It all starts out rather well with a cracker theme tune set to an impressive montage that tells you how our two intrepid heroes Tommynaught and his trusted companion Beak-Beak find themselves in the situation they are in. I was generally enjoying the first hour even though the two leads have absolutely no chemistry and say very little to each other let alone the gamer. There is no feedback at all from either character concerning the game world around you. Armikrog simply just devolves into a click everything in site festival while controlling both characters in the hope one of them will respond to the action or say something. Most of the time they simply just stand silently on the spot gazing off in separate distances leaving the player wondering why on earth they are investing time and effort into a game where the two lead characters are so disinterested in their own adventure.

The world they populate is also completely devoid of any kind of life outside of the ghosts that once populated the fortress they hole themselves up in after escaping a vicious looking monster with an anthropomorphic tongue at the start of the game. Items picked up during the play are never given any sort of description simply getting stashed inside the stomach of Tommynaught. There isn't even a way to see what items Tommynaught has stored via an inventory. Even by old school standards some of the design decisions made are so archaic that you simply have to wonder what the hell was going through these peoples minds, if anything at all, as they construted this ill-fated labour of love. Music is once again composed by the same composer from The Neverhood and while the soundtrack is incredibly sparse what is on offer is often quite delightful. I just wish more of it would have played since the game is just filled with so many uncomfortable silences. Things do pick up towards the end but by then the game has worn out all of its welcome and most gamers and fans of the original The Neverhood will have ceased caring as the clouds of disappointment hang thickly in the air.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=534284738
So now the important question is do I recommend Armikrog? At the full of price of $24.99 - HELL NO! If you can pick up the game for less then $10 then I would say - YES. There is some genuine awe and wonder at work in all the modeled clay environments and at that price they may just be worth fighting your way through tedium to discover. It is such a pity that all the goodwill the game generates in its opening and concluding sections is squandered by a middle that looks like it was cobbled together on the fly with little to no passion for genre or the hobby. You have ask yourself why did they even bother and if the truth be told it's because they simply just didn't care or care enough to actually put something worthwhile together because Armikrog is sadly a failure on most accounts. Sad news indeed for fans of The Neverhood.

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater

reviewText:
TL;DR: Game not worth the full price by far. The OST might be nice by itself, though you have to decide for yourself how much you want to pay for 17 songs/51 minutes.

Let me start with the good stuff:
+ Visual style (Claymation) is nice, though bland animations and static lighting ruin the effect.
+ Music is great, though it occasionally just stops in between.

Now for the disillusioning rest:
- This is not a game, it's barely a trailer! My steam library says 4h, though that's because I was cooking something in between! Actual gameplay is more around 1.5h, and that even only due to unskippable videos, forcedly slow waiting-puzzles, no possibility to run and the requirement to re-walk through every location just as you’re about to finish.
- Gameplay missed every piece of usability learned during the last 10-20 years… There are no indications for what is clickable, what is not, or if you just missed the seemingly random click areas. Obvious interactive elements, which are just not yet active, are simply not clickable without any indication why this might be the case. Things that are interactive have terrible click zones, which sometimes leaves no option as to leave and reenter a room in hopes to make the clicking work again. And occasionally buttons have to be pressed by your companion dog, because they’re 3cm too low for the main character (who can’t be bothered with bending down that much).
- Even the level design occasionally doesn’t make sense. Complete sections could have been simply skipped or severely shortened without losing any part of gameplay, story or mechanic. On the other hand there is one part with critical information for the finale, which is impossible to revisit as soon as you actually need this information (spoiler-less hint: as soon as you get the “translations”, take a screenshot and learn the spoken sequence by heart!).
- Finally even the story does not make sense (It doesn’t affect the gameplay at all, but be warned: spoilers ahead): Three brothers are sent out into space to collect a critical energy source for their home planet. The protagonist randomly crashes somewhere, flees into a castle full of convenient riddles, has to safe a baby in between, and suddenly one of the brothers turns up being evil, having caused havoc apparent minutes before the game started, and threatening you for no reason. All of a sudden the “ancient” texts turn into a live commentary, and the whole setup was only to give you the power source you needed anyway after testing your honor? The third brother is only ever mentioned in the end without any other context other than to try and tie in a forced sequel?

I backed this game on Kickstarter, only because I was so interested in the Claymation style. Good thing, the game was already delayed so often, so I already wrote off that money, otherwise I’d be (more) annoyed by this waste of money.

reviewText:
Warning: Minor spoilers ahead. You'll see why.

In my personal opinion, The Neverhood was a game whose charm arose primarily from the presentation and the unspoken intrigue. You have no idea who or what Klaymen, or for that matter, anything else is, and set out to find the story of the world and yourself by solving a series of often lackluster puzzles. The things that really string you along are the occasional zany claymation sequences, and the infodisks scattered around that contain segments of Willie telling the game's story in snippets. It has a hook that holds it through, and the puzzles, while cumbersome and uninspired, are not usually a major nuisance as long as you have pen and paper handy.

Armikrog dispels half of its intrigue out of the gate by endowing its protagonists with, star talent as they may be, some of the most boring (and poorly recorded) voices I've ever heard, and giving you a synopsis of the backstory in the damn title sequence. You want to know the story? Here it is: you need to find a rare energy source on another planet to help sustain your people, but end up crash-landing during your trip.

The game assassinates its own intrigue before you even get to play it. I don't have any questions about who these oddballs are, they're just some dumb shmucks on a delivery run. There is a Hall of Records equivalent a short ways into the game detailing the life of an enslaved miner from some point in history that is infinitely more interesting than whatever is going on here!

Once you do start playing, you'll probably get about 3 screens in before the utter purple monkey dishwasher leaps of logic required to progress start to sink in. Blocking a doorway with a large, fuzzy creature will cause a tentacle elevator to descend from a trapdoor in the ceiling. The thing those tentacles are attached to is actually a key item and massive plot-dump device (speaking in an alien language so as to blue-ball you as much as possible with regards to deciphering what lore is left to uncover), but only if interacted with while playing solo as Beak-Beak. There are no prompts or hints whatsoever towards this. The incidental characters so far have not been a bizarre face sticking out of a TV, a murderous green crablike creature, nor a giant robot with a teddy bear. Instead, they have been Abrahant Lincoln and Thomas Jeffersant. Get it? Like the historical figures, except ants. Ha. Ha. Ha.

And then I spent a solid hour working on the Planetarium puzzle, which is of the breed of puzzles that you know exactly what to do with from one quick prod at it, but takes an agonizing length of time to actually execute.

It is also at this point that I feel the need to mention that the game is, despite its delays, bugged out the butt. Clicking hotspots are extremely finicky sometimes, the wall-mounted rider will always get stuck on certain sections until you manage to dislodge it, and clicking on the wrong thing at the wrong time WILL break the game and render progress impossible. Of course, if you don't click on everything in every possible way then you're not going to find out how to progress either!

Neverhood was an interesting story told in a fantastical manner, with a series of dumb puzzles standing in your way as an excuse to call it a game. Armikrog may yet have a fascinating story to begin to unravel, but has been such an abjectly miserable gameplay experience that I can't bring myself to care enough to continue bashing my head against it.

It's still well animated, at least.

reviewText:
As it is right now, it's so broken that you can easily lock yourself out of the ending.

Game is ridden with progression-breaking bugs, from items that appear in your inventory before you pick them up; the ending easily becoming unreachable if you accidentally miss a thing with no way of coming back to fix it; some broken sound playback (audio cues playing where they shouldn't or stopping halfway through); as well as iffy detection boxes that make you think some key items are just part of the background and can't be interacted with.

Not only that but the game itself is very poorly designed, a lot of puzzles require extensive pixel hunting to be solved, since there are absolutely no hints to what to do.

On top of all that, the soundtrack isn't even in high bitrate (only 256 kbps MP3), opposite to what would be expected of any official game soundtrack in the year 2015.

Even though my playtime is 5 hours, I must say that at least 40% of that time was spent mindlessly backtracking and clicking on things searching for solutions that weren't even there, and searching the steam community for said solutions.

As sad as it makes me (been a fan of The Neverhood since my childhood and been hyping up for this game since the kickstarter campaign was launched), I cannot recommend this game, since as it is right now, the game is not at all worth its cost, and regardless of the cost, it's highly unsatisfying to play, as well as very short and repetitive.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I've backed this game on the Kickstarter.

A biased review from the guy who played the ♥♥♥♥ out of The Neverhood and then some more:

It pains me immensely to not recommend this game. The promise was amazing: the team that made The Neverhood, including the composer, to make a brand new clay stop motion adventure. But the result is just not up to the hype.

The main problem is repetitiveness. They happened to make a set of puzzles and managed to reuse them 4 times over. I kid you not.

The story is quite lazy, unimaginative and, frankly, boring.

Sprites look quite lazy on top of the backgrounds, they don't feel like  they are out there in the real environment. Maybe that's the result of modern technologies making problems be more noticeable, I don't really know.

Music variety is lacking.

All the things I loved from The Neverhood, besides amusingly insane art style are just not there.

You could expect to see a fan of the old game disappointed with the new one not being the same thing over, but most of the issues still stand even without the comparison: technical issues, repetitiveness, boring and short story.

It's very sad, but I can't recommend Armikrog at its full price. Get it when it's on sale, or better yet get your hands on The Neverhood, it runs well via scummvm on any modern operating system and is far superior to this.

reviewText:
While able to produce great looking graphics, TenNaple and Co. have seemingly not learned a single thing about designing adventure games & puzzles in the 19 years since The Neverhood came out.  Here's the shopping list of egregious problems:
- Tedious, repeated puzzles.
- Buggy as all heck - buttons or pickups sometimes do not work the first tome you try them, and then suddenly do the next time you click them; music cuts in and out, and more. I hit a game-breaking bug that caused me to have to quit the game and restart in order to dislodge my character from where they were stuck in the level.
- Nonsensical design and mechanics

After two delays, this still feels unfinished.  Even so, it does not matter how long this may have taken to come out - the game design is simply 20 years out of date and not much fun.

reviewText:
In looking at many other reviews, it seems like people don't really recall the Neverhood and form unbalanced comparisons to a whimsical game from 2 decades ago.

That said, the Neverhood has always been one of my favorite games of all time. The developers did a wonderful job in imagining their world, developing lovable characters and flushing out a compelling plot with only a page worth of dialogue. The Neverhood was very short, very easy and more charming than anything else. I would encourage anyone who thinks the Neverhood was SO MUCH superior to Armikrog to go back and re-play it, then see if those comparisons still hold up. I did, and I don't think Armikrog is worse than the Neverhood. For the most part, I think it is as good.

Strengths in both games are largely the same. The dev team pulls together a very charming cast and a quirky environment that is fun to explore, staples of the original concept in the Neverhood. Contemporary games have expanded considerably in content, so it's not surprising to see gripes about the game being too short. Truth be told, I found the puzzles in Armikrog much more difficult than in the Neverhood, so my 1st playthrough clocked in around 12hrs. Add 2hrs if you want to read the new Hall of Records."

The game's launch was mired in glitches unfortunately. Running on Windows 10
date: I only experienced trouble with looping "P" having a tantrum (happened only once) and the music cutting in and out infrequently. No save glitches etc. So I'd hardly call the game broken. reviewText:
Being a fan of the original Neverhood (Skullmonkeys was OK but meh), preordering this game was a no brainer at first.
After completing the game and testing some stuff out I can say it doesn't give you
enough bang for your buck. The initial delays were fine by me, as I'd rather wait and get
a clean playable version than just some half-♥♥♥♥♥ pieced together ''game''
(looking at you early access alpha...).
Instead we get a nice looking Neverhood clone, which undoubtedly, most people wanted
in the first place, but lacking the core elements that made us all fall in love with the original.

Cons:
The humour is lackluster
Game breaking bugs can occur (getting stuck in a wall)
Progression bugs (not being able to progress without reloading a save)
Save files don't work properly at all times
The menu, or the lack thereof
Inconsistencies when returning to previous areas or completing tasks more than once
Visual bugs
Audio bugs (no music or sound effects)
The puzzles are repetitive and boring for the most part

Pros:
Claymation <3
Soundtrack (Good, but not on par with you know who)

All in all, I'd say get this game and try it out for yourself but only during a sale. The feel of Neverhood 2 was never so close and yet so far away at the same time, a crying shame...

reviewText:
After my first playthrough I was slightly disappointed and I was left wanting a more, maybe my expectations were too high, but now, playing it for the second time, it sort of grew on me and I'd say it's a worthy companion to The Neverhood (my favorite game of all time).

I loved having to write stuff down in my notebook, just like I had to with The Neverhood the first time. The art style, the music, the voice acting, the story (to a certain point) and especially the puzzles are all superb. This is fun little game, my three main gripes would be the abrupt ending, the underused villain and the lack of a pointer, the latter really being just nitpicking. And I guess I would like it if it was a BIT longer, I managed to play through it for the first time in one sitting, in just about 4-5 hours.

So while this is a great game, it does have it's flaws, though that doesn't hinder much of it's enjoyability, at least not for me. Support more out there"

So I've completed the game despite the bugs, and towards the end I started to enjoy it... But I really think I should've been enjoying it the whole way through, not just the final 2 puzzles and the last cutscene. First of all a puzzle game CAN'T have bugs, there were so many times when my progression was blocked and I just wasn't sure if it was my fault or the games. Something a point and click adventure game SHOULD have is charm, and this game did... towards the end. I didn't feel engaged in the story at all until the ending sequence and by that time it was too late, I'd just spent however many hours angrily doing puzzles in a bland world just to complete it.

And thats so sad because what these guys created could've been SO AMAZING, and it was SO CLOSE. For example, why was it so quiet? So much of the game I spent listening to the wind. I don't know if they needed more time, or more funds, but it seems to me like they couldn't finish the game with what they had.

reviewText: 1) The Neverhood, this is not. It wasn't meant to be, so get that expectation out of your head before playing. The story isn't nearly as thrilling; that beautiful minimalism is gone and replaced by a sort of hollow Saturday-morning-adventure feel. You learn to live with it.\n2) There's a real lack of balance with puzzles. For the vast majority of the game, you're working room-to-room through fairly linear puzzles. Near the end, things become exceedingly abstract: the final puzzle, many people have chosen walkthroughs over the actual work of translating the runic shapes (best done by watching these special FMVs a second time after playing through the whole game, hunting down certain NPCs).\n3) The game is SHORT. My logged time, just over 4 hours, is what it took me to clear this game. reviewText:
Armikrog is a Kickstarted spiritual successor to The Neverhood (1996).  I was a huge fan of The Neverhood which greatly fueled my anticipation for Armikrog.  Armikrog delivers exactly what you would expect from the spiritual successor: unique visuals with a playful soundtrack.  And then it builds on The Neverhood with the addition of quality voice acting that perfectly fits inside this fantastical world.

Gameplay is basic point & click.  You can't even view your inventory.  If you click on something that requires an item you already have, Tommy reaches into his... pocket... and grabs the right item.

The puzzles are typically nonsensical and sometimes completely irrational just as you'd expect from such a game, not too dissimilar to The Neverhood.

A serious lack of options, such as audio sliders, is disappointing.  The captions don't match up to exactly what the characters say, but they aren't wildly different either (I recall one comment that was WILDLY different but it felt intentional).  Several audio issues such as missing sound effects, characters talking when they aren't even there.

The game uses several unfortunate ways to lengthen the game. First, it recycles a few puzzles.  Second, it uses walking and retracing steps unecessarily.

There isn't much interaction between the characters.  Not a whole lot of dialogue.  With such great voice talent, I was hoping to hear more of it.

The game is quite short, probably less than half the length of The Neverhood.

I know the price point is going to scare away people that aren't into the point & click genre- and I can't blame them for that.  Honestly, I would wait for it to come down in price.

Maybe it's the nostalgia of The Neverhood that got to me.  Maybe it's the aesthetic; you can tell a ton of serious love and hard work went into the claymation.  Maybe it's the off-the-wall music, which consistently lets you know you are in a foreign world with bizarre creatures.

See my let's play if you'd like to find out if this game locks you in as it did me:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ICvQ8GNx568&list=PLZbmcHZ8TjKdcgeq2C9evn1X0iQ-1fPId

reviewText:
Decent follow-up to the Neverhood with unfortunate bugs from being rushed out the door.

I've been a huge Neverhood fan since I was a kid. If you're coming from that to this, Armikrog is not going to quite live up to what the Neverhood was, but still serves as a decent homage when your options are kinda limited for this genre. The same great production values are there, and you'll need a notebook on hand to draw down the various nonsense symbols that will be used in puzzles later. It hits the right notes for that mix of bizarre and comedy.

The game was clearly rushed for launch, even after Pencil Test Studios had to push back the release date twice, and it shows. Early on, you'll run into issues where Beak-Beak can't hit a button, and you'll be fumbling around clicking everywhere to get Tommy or Beak-Beak to do what you want them to. A lot of puzzle solutions aren't intuitive because of this -- one of the major gameplay solutions can be missed entirely unless you're clicking around everywhere. I also found various instances where Tommy would jump to unexpected places in the terrain.

This may also be a bug, but the game is somewhat silent. I mean this in that you'll find that sometimes no music or sound effects seem to play for a couple of rooms. The music that does play will usually be gone sooner than later, so a lot of the time Armikrog feels very desolate and eerie compared to Neverhood (and that's saying a lot). This is coupled with the fact that while the characters are voice-acted, they don't have a lot of lines at all. For all the craziness that happens in the game, they have surprisingly little to talk about to each other.

The game will probably take you about 4-6 hours to complete, at what looks like 100% (seeing absolutely everything there is to see). I can think of only one puzzle that was an actual head-scratcher and took a bit of thought. The rest were on the easier side of what you'd expect from Neverhood, and were mostly symbol-matching from clues you'd seen earlier in the game. Pretty straightforward.

Not a bad game by any means, but the cards were stacked against it in trying to match The Neverhood, and the game was clearly rushed out the door when they could have spent another month to give it the polish it needed.

8/10. Try to grab it when it's on sale for around $15. $25 is steep for what you get -- and that's coming from a Kickstarter backer and huge fan of the source material.

Firstly, it's not as good as The Neverhood. Yeah, of course it's a tough one to live up to, and it's not fair to compare the games like for like.... WRONG. If they raise money for this game on the back of Hey! Remember Neverhood? We want to do more of that!" then they invite comparisons. And it fails miserably.

It's nice to have HD graphics

reviewText:
I played this for about an hour and got quite far. However, this game is half-finished. Here is a list of problems that have no sign of being addressed by the developers:

UI elements appear to be either missing or ill-conceived: uses default mouse cursor that doesn't highlight or notify what things can be interacted with/picked up, save/load is hidden away in 'options', no inventory, you just automatically use the right object at the time.
It's possible for the game to be incompletable due a bug that allows you to go past a locked room with no way of returning.
Some of the puzzles aren't really puzzles - they are just arbitary roadblocks that you couldn't possibly guess because the game is incositent with what you can'can't interact with.
There's a puzzle that will make any new parent tear their hair out as you have to complete it while listening to a distraught baby.
Various buttons can't, then can be interacted with depending on if you've completed prior steps (instead of letting you use a button anyway and being told 'it does nothing', which would make more sense and was done by every other PnC Adventure ever).

It's such a shame as the animation/art is really cool. I didn't finish it, but I'm also reading reports that it's very short as well.

reviewText:
I've backed Armikrog on Kickstarer and was waiting for the game with excitement.  Unfortunately thanks to the bugs and crude user interface I would not recommend Armikrog. Maybe future updates change that..?

My list of the biggest 'fun killers':

Game uses plain windows cursor:
There is no clue whether the user is pointing at some item or interactive element. I've ended clicking everything.. So much fun..

Bugs:
Sometimes clicking on stuff that supposed to be interactive does nothing.. And you get stuck.
There are problems with music playback

Game interface:
No warning when overwriting savegame.. And you are toasted.
Double clicking on savegame does nothing, user actually have to select item from the list and then click the open button. Come on, we have 2015 not 1997...
I kept accidentally switching characters.
I had hard time to actually do stuff. One glaring example: At one location when clicking on the lever Tommynaut does nothing …, but when user clicks on the device from which the lever sticks out Tommynaut happily pulls the lever.

No 1920x1200 resolution support.
In full screen everything is stretched vertically. In windowed mode the game offers the same level of immersion as the Solitaire.

Other:
Soundtrack is VERY short; the one from the previous game the Neverhood is light years ahead.
Some locations are a bit on the blurry side
When Tommynaut or the dog speaks it sounds out of place.

reviewText: The spiritual successor to The Neverhood
date:
a claymation point-and-click adventure game notable for being headed by Earthworm Jim creator Douglas TenNapel, after nineteen years Armikrog was definitely worth the wait.

In many ways, Armikrog basically IS The Neverhood but simply updated, right down to very similar stories that Neverhood fans will probably pick up on once the villain is revealed - and this is far from a bad thing. The game is filled with just as much fantastic claymation (with some 2D animation incorporated) and TenNapel's imaginative visual splendor as The Neverhood, perhaps even moreso thanks to the advancements in technology since 1996. Terry Scott Taylor's soundtrack is also exceptional, once again capturing the unique flavor of The Neverhood's iconic musical style. Though the game only has a handful of cutscenes, Michael J. Nelson, Jon Heder and Rob Paulsen do add some entertaining voice acting to them.

My only real complaint is that the game is sadly kind of short. I don't consider myself a point-and-click adventure puzzle expert in the slightest and I still managed to beat the game in about 5 hours, though I did have help from some friends who were also playing along with me. Hilariously the longest I got stuck was probably just trying to find a lever that was camouflaged among some debris.

There's a lot of other early reviews saying the game is currently very buggy, however during my playthrough I only encounted one or two extremely minor glitches, and certainly none that were game-breaking. Plus I think it's silly to not recommend a game just because it hasn't even been released for an entire day yet and there's still a few things the developers need to patch out and probably will within the next couple days if not sooner. Still, if you are concerned about bugs and aren't in a huge hurry, maybe wait a little bit for those last few issues to get ironed out.

Armikrog is a must-own for fans of The Neverhood, anyone who enjoys truly original and visually stunning games, and old school adventure gamers who miss the days where you actually had to get a pen and paper and write things down. You can get it now for $25 (or less if on sale), but for me it was well worth the more than $100 I pledged to the Kickstarter campaign.

reviewText: the art and clay give this game a good feeling. but it falls short on the neverhood in every area.\nI can see the effort behind it and I can see what it wanted to be. But guys, you should have thought about what made the neverhood so great before even atempting to make a successor: for example, the neverhood is great because you develop a sense of how the whole 3D world is mapped out and learn to navigate and come to love it. but in armikrogm it doesnt feel like a world, it feels like a constant mash up of rooms made from fitted together layers of seperatley recorded clay, and this makes the whole thing feel flat and insted of navigating, exploring and walking around you just pace back and forth in room upon room. also the storey is hardly explained in enough detail and beak beak feels like he is just their for gameplay purpose because the relationship of the two main characters of the game is not developed at all, making it all feel forced.\nThe biggest concern for me is also something that no-one else had mentioned, the Neverhood felt solid because everything was one and all the rooms where the same size and klaymans slow pace actually gave a nicer feel to the game, however, in Armikrog some rooms were hugely zoomed out, ruining the mystery and feel of the game also the game felt really flimsy and that every action and movement had no real weight behind it, and all those layers also ruined the soul of the game and it feels rushed. the other con for me was the music, partley because it barley playes and also is sort of boring and ambiant, it is good but not what i was expecting from Taylor. where is the catchy giberish and acoustic gituar!? i heard the boo-ha-ha song and it put my expectations high because i loved it and then the music disaponted it is like something out of Rayman, not the neverhood. also the bugs could be fixed but it still would not fix the feel of the game. reviewText:
I'm usually not one to write a review for a game that I don't recommend, but I think I need to for this.

Being a big fan of The Neverhood, I was obviously very excited when the Kickstarter for Armikrog launched almost two and a half years ago. However, after finally having gotten to play it, I can't help but getting a sour taste in my mouth.

While the art design and animation is superb, the aspect that it truly falls flat on is the puzzles, and that's pretty bad for an adventure game. There are truly only a handful of variations of puzzles throughout the whole thing, only ramping up in complexity each time, and the only way I can easily explain them is: Tedious. It felt like a chore to work through these puzzles, and I was actively looking forward to the whole thing being over after a while. I can only describe it as being boring.

It's sad, but this turned out to be a prime example of why Kickstarter is such a gamble. You can see the love and dedication that the team put into this, but it is also painfully obvious that they ran out of time and money a lot sooner than they thought they would, leaving an end product that is neither satisfying or ultimately worth your time.

reviewText:
Armikrog starts with a bombastic, hyperactive animation, followed by a theme song similar to the ones from the ’80s and ’90s cartoons. Before you get a chance to come around after this epic blow to all your senses (or in my case, nostalgia) comes another amazing animation, this time in a stop-motion technique in the sumptuous claymation style from the rest of the game. The visual style is definitely the main selling point of this game, and a large number of models and locations were really made from plasticine/clay and other materials and later the photos were incorporated into scenes that we see in the final product. As a spiritual successor to the almost two decades old game, The Neverhood, Armikrog also places the player in a weird world full of mysteries that invite you to investigate. It’s a pity that the rest of the game’s quality does not follow up to the one it starts with.

Armikrog would have easily been discarded as an amateur half-product if it didn’t look so lovely and unusual. It’s a great shame that because of programmers’ and designers’ incompetence all this hard work is gone to waste, all those stunning landscapes and objects which someone’s been building for months and carefully animated picture by picture are now in the same boat with some of the most irritating puzzles I've seen in the last few years. Considering that it doesn’t take more than 3-4 hours to finish the game, the price of 25€ is an insult. Just like Broken Age before it, Armikrog is a million-worth Kickstarter project that fails to justify it’s pedigree and unsuccessfully relies on the good will and nostalgia of fans.

Full review here: http://play-zine.com/2015/11/review-armikrog/

reviewText:
For this review I'm ignoring the bugs and glitches that came with the initial release as they've been patched for the most part since then. With all that aside, Armikrog just wasn't as enjoyable as I hoped. This wasn't a hope for Neverhood 2 or any sort of nostalgia, but more a hope that it'd be a decent point and click puzzle adventure. It wasn't.

I backed this on kickstarter a good while back, when the opening cutscene was animated and looked pretty awesome. The animation is a great part of the game, there's no denying that. However the gameplay leaves a lot to be desired. The lack of any examine dialogue makes the larger puzzles rather unintuative, and I found myself coming across a lot of solutions through dumb luck as opposed to any form of logic.

Pixel hunting is not a good mechanic for a puzzle game, and the problems are made even worse with really shoddy clickzones. I found myself jumping off tentacles when I didn't want to, and being unable to start puzzles as I was clicking on an obvious button rather than the drawing next to it.

I can't say I was that interested in the story either. The motivations for Tommynaut and Beak-Beak aren't exactly that clear, and although towards the end the dialogue makes it more coherant, I just stopped caring and just wanted to get the game over and done with. I can't recommend, even on sale, as I'd have asked for a refund if I had got it from Steam outright.

reviewText: Fairly mediocre adventure game. Unfortunate to see Earthworm Jim's creator continue to make a game that suffers the same mistakes two decades later, which is to say that Armikrog feels like a game designed by visual artists instead of actual game designers. I will give it credit for being very aesthetically pleasing, but under the surface I found it to be a very sloppy, toothless gameplay experience.\n\nI found very few of the puzzles to be particularly well-designed. Many are simply designed to be time-consuming rather than require actual problem solving (the most egregious examples of which are repeated multiple times over the course of the game). The game utilizes a very minimalist interface that sounds fine on paper, but in practice is hampered by a complete lack of feedback and some appallingly broken hotspots. On more than one occasion I tried to perform an action to no avail and was stumped until it randomly decided to accept my inputs for no discernible reason. The player isn't even allowed to make the protagonists press buttons if pressing it won't do anything; they have to solve the corresponding puzzle first. This is compounded by the game's lack of any kind of feedback, leaving the player to wonder if they're not solving it correctly or if the game is outright broken. Maybe it would have been too costly to get Tommynaut's voice actor to say Hmm... nope. That didn't do anything."

reviewText:
I want to like Armikrog, but I think The Neverhood spoiled me many years before...

As a kickstarter project, it's a charming throw-back to the stop motion Claymation that made games like The Neverhood so unique. I will probably reference The Neverhood quite a lot in this review. It's perhaps a bit unfair to compare Armikrog and The Neverhood, truth be told. But it's rather difficult not to when describing some of the nuances of Armikrog; as both games draw from the same creative water source.

Armikrog has a wonderful introduction sequence, with great music from Terry Taylor, and oozing with fun clay-sculpted, stop-motion imagination. Hitting planet side has a real feeling of wonder of what's in store for us! I wonder what catchy ditty the first room will have!?


Until the gameplay starts.

The world:
One of the things that made The Neverhood so immersive, was the amount of interactive things in the world. The mushroom tree, the scorpion booger monster clipping Klayman's head off if he strayed too close to the door. The freaking drain, that is clearly signposted as being 'deadly', and can end your game if you jump down it anyway. To name but a few instances where the world can be interacted with, and interact with you. The areas are all distinct, yet skillfully connected.

Armikrog offers nothing to really 'pull' players into the world around them. And what little there is, it's just another vehicle to advance the story. The ants were kind of cool, but are random with no actual context or reason for being in Armikrog. Abraham Lincoln ant with a puzzle clue, right next to a completely unrelated puzzle? It's not immediately clear whether the two are somehow connected ( they aren't), so I spent a frustrated half an hour on that alone.

Story:
The overarching story is communicated predominantly through the ceiling barnacles, and I find it a bit neat that the developers used a very particular language for them. There's no real incentive for the player to bother learning it themselves however: the story isn't deep enough to warrant that level of commitment.

The cassettes that contained the Neverhood story were brilliant for one simple reason: they made learning the story, a puzzle in itself. You explored this colourful world and catchy soundtrack, Klayman's rythmic plodding your only companion, but the world fed you bits of information here and there. And each thread organically flowed into the next, weaving the whole story together by the end.

You can get the gist of what happened at Armikrog very, very quickly. And the only drive forward after that, is to find some power source that you have no idea what it looks like, and a baby that exists to forcibly inject an occasional audio puzzle at pre-determined points in the progression.

Puzzles (the thing you absolutely want to get right in your point & click puzzle adventure game)
The puzzles aren't particularly rewarding to solve, and the process of figuring them out is monotonous. There's really no other way to describe them.
Beak Beak is a nice physical design (but I was always a sucker for Barking birds), but the buddy system feels very tacked on, and it's nothing groundbreaking in this day and age.


Music:
The music ost is worth getting hold of, and has just the right amount of nostalgic style, while still doing it's own thing; a treat to listen to in-game. When it plays anyway.
Which leads me onto another thing that bothers me: through experimentation, it appears the music play as a nod of yeah you're doing it right" as you progress. But if you hang around too much
hoursPlayed: and you will be back to silence. It's never enough time to really appreciate it

reviewText:
So despite my early frustrations I did stick with it and have to say this is a nice little puzzler with a huge amount of charm and personality... but it's not without its flaws.

On the positive side, as I said, it does have a lot charm about it. The writing, voice acting and the fantastic use of claymation make for a hugely enjoyable gaming experience. You can tell there has been some real passion put into the character design and the creation of all these incredibly tactile levels. This game has a lot of heart.

Also this is an adventure game where you don't have to worry about your inventory and the usual will this item work with this object". That feels really refreshing. And
recommended:
there is a nice variety of puzzles (some of which do actually force you to pay attention and take notes). But once you peel back that thin layer plasticine that makes up the enticing veneer of this game I'm afraid the underlying armature is a little wonky.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4bGliGbrRGA

The puzzles feel inconsitent. The clues (and the puzzles themselves) vary from the blatantly obvious to not even cryptic just plain unhelpful. For the longest time I was stuck on one section because at no point does it indicate that Beak-Beak can interact with the creatures in Armikrog. After learning that I could breeze through the rest of the game but it was not something that was obvious at the time or even hinted at.

Also some of the puzzles are incredibly repetitive and feel like they are there just to drag out and artifically extend the length of the game.

Also
hoursPlayed: I can understand a few bugs here and there but actually being able to to walk through closed doors or not being able to interact with buttons (no matter how many times or where you click on them) is a pretty big flaw for a point & click game. And the save system is incredibly buggy
voteText: more than once I had to replay entire sections as the game failed to save.\n\nI suppose for me Armikrog doesn't really feel like a million bucks (or rather the $974.5K raised on Kickstarter). Yes

If it was in the knd of $15 price range and some of the bugs were patched out I would probably recommend it but as it stands at the moment I'd say maybe hold off on buying it unless you a die hard adventure game or The Neverhood fan."

reviewText:
TL;DR:
You want some puzzle? Get Grimrock 1 or 2, or Portal 1 or 2, or basically anything other than that.
You want some art? Play Neverhood or watch some pixar/dreamworks/disney/whatever movie.
You want to kill some time? Go to cinema. Game is 2-3 hours long anyway.

Good luck getting stuck near a button that just wont press, because its supposed to be pressed by the dog. Oh, the next one is supposed to be pressed by the guy. And one after that? The dog. The thing is: they are all the same.
Good luck doing mundane chores of pressing button 10 times (to check if you've pressed it enough times you have to go to the adjacent room).
Good luck solving the same door puzzle 4 times. And lullaby puzzle 3 times. Thank god they have different solutions every time. Too bad the solution procedure is the same every time.

Pros: good art and nice soundtrack.
Cons: it's bugged, it's got horrible unresponsive controls, a quarter of puzzles are counterintuitive, a third of puzzles are mundane chores, repetitive puzzles. Oh, and it takes 2-3 hours to finish the game, if you wont get stuck on a particularly stubborn button for 1.5 hours.

reviewText:
Armikrog is finally here and does the game live up to the hype? Well, yes and no.

In a nutshell, Armikrog is a beautiful game from beginning to end. The claymation aesthestic is gorgeous and makes it stand out than other games on the market. Both the characters and backgrounds are delightful to look at and you can tell a lot of work was put into it. Unfortunately, if only the same thing can be said about the gameplay.

Armikrog is your standard point 'n' click game that requires no input on the keyboard (except for saving which will get to later), just the mouse. The problem is is that the game doesn't do a good job of explaining that to you as there is no tutorial or guideline to tell you the basics. The game assumes that you know how to change characters, that there's no inventory menu, and that the save/load screen is in the option menu, which is weird.

Overall, Armikrog feels very outdated as the UI design is lacking and the puzzle solving requires you to memorize icons and patterns. I believe this is what the developers are going for but as much as I enjoy nostalgia, it just doesn't feel right. I don't want to be writing down stuff and halt my progress - I just want to keep playing. Throughout the game, there are these green conveyor belts that you use to move from one area to the next. I find personally find them a bore because there's nothing much going on in the background. It's a filler more or less. In addition, I had trouble of knowing how to stop the conveyer belt and exit the vehicle. Again, the game assumes you know how to do it.

Soundwise, it's great. The soundtrack is most definitely the highlight of Armikrog and I find myself listening to it on my iPhone. Unfortunately, the music tends to cut off or starts off out of the blue which can break the gameplay experience. Same goes with the voice over, which is of low quality as if the voice actors recorded them in their bedroom and not in a real professional studio.

The biggest disappointment for me is how short the game is. It took me about 3 hours to complete it and when I first saw the credits, I thought it was joke. It's strange how to story got resolved very quickly just as things were about to get more interesting. I was hoping to see more claymation cutscenes but it didn't happen. I also wanted to explore more of the environment but there's only so much you can see or do, which is a letdown.

Again, I was disappointed when the game ended but the next day, I played it again and ended up enjoying it than before. I guess I began to appreciate what the game has to offer the second time around. Plus, I have a soft spot for claymation. Despite its technical flaws, Armikrog is pretty enjoyable. It's by no means a masterpiece but you have to give it credit for the amount of effort the developers put into making Armikrog a reality. There is no way this game can ever be made by a AAA publisher in this day and age so be thankful that this game isn't just another mindless shooter.

If you are into claymation like me and are looking for a one-of-a-kind game with catchy music and interesting world to explore, I'd say give Armikrog a try but if you're in no hurry, just wait until it goes on sale.


Summary:
Pros:
Claymation goodness!
Fun protagonists
Catchy soundtrackCons:
Very outdated UI design
A few bugs here and there
Puzzles require memorizing
A lot of flash but no substance
Voice over don't sound good
Very short game

SCORE:
Gameplay - 0.5
Graphics - 1
Audio - 0.5
Replay Value: - 0.5
Overall - 0.5
TOTAL: 3/5 Stars

reviewText: You're going to see a lot of reviews here dissecting why this isn't the Neverhood. That's fine. I will say that when I sat down to play it, I loved the visuals, I had fun drawing the non-sensical symbols all over pieces of paper to keep track of puzzles, and I had fun... playing a game. Whodathunk. Given, I didn't run into any of the 'game-breaking' bugs I've read about. Most of the times I got frustrated, it was just because I wasn't following the old adventure game adage 'when in doubt, click EVERYTHING'. Sometimes you've got to be methodical to realize certain characters interact with certain ways with objects, it doesn't sugarcoat anything.\n\nAnyways, my main critique is just that I would love more. More puzzles, more cutscenes, more animation, more voice acting etc. And that is fine. That means I really enjoyed the work that was put out there and I hope to see more from the Pencil Test folks.

reviewText:
It's really tough to downrate such a beautiful game that so much effort has clearly gone into but unfortunately (in my opinion) this game is unpolished and needs work.  It's probably worth me adding that I have never played the Neverhood,  so that hasn't factored into my review.

Pros
+ Fantastic aesthetics - the claymation is truly brilliant
+ Great music (although I hear that for some it doesn't always play)
+ Interesting puzzles

Cons

- Dreadful UI. I know this is a matter of preference, so you may well feel differently, but for me this just wasn't what I would expect from a modern point and click adventure. The cursor is the standard windows one - this may not sound like a big deal but I don't ever remember seeing this on a game I've paid for... I was so surprised in fact that I thought the game hadn't loaded correctly. Pixel hunting is rife in this game. While I can understand that some may not want the feeling of being handheld by having clear hotspots or a dynamic cursor, the game just doesn't give you feedback leading to a bit of frustration, clicking on everything repeatedly. Why? The hotspot sensitivity/radius is really odd (sometimes you have to click in a slightly odd place to get something to work); sometimes the clicks don't seem to register even though you're clicking on something that's definitely interactive; and sometimes when you're clicking on, for example, a button 'too early' (ie a puzzle somewhere needs to be solved first) you'd expect the character to press it (and it then does nothing). Actually the character does nothing at all, there's no feedback/sounds or anything, so you're left thinking perhaps it isn't something you can interact with (even though it is). I can't help but think that this is not where the puzzles are supposed to be. Clicking on a button for 10 minutes to get something to happen just isn't fun. I don't expect puzzle hints, I do expect some even vague clues on how to play the game. There's no inventory, for example - in fact it's purely pointing and clicking, there are no keyboard controls.

- Very little story or character development. Yes, there is a (text only) novella part way through the game but usually in a point and click I'd get a decent story propelling me throughout that compels me to keep playing. I didn't get that from this game at all. There's very little dialogue and not as much humour as I had expected.

- Lots of bugs, some of which are minor, others are more major - you can get yourself stuck in no-win situations, for example, and in some instances the save game function is not working properly (for instance when overwriting a previous save). I understand it only launched yesterday (at time of writing) so I'm really hoping these things will be fixed soon.

- Quality on the cinematics/sound seems poor, as though it had been over-compressed.

- Bit short for the price at (approximately) 3-5 hours playtime. Little replay value (as it is linear)

Ultimately although the devs doing the claymation did a stellar job, I really feel this game has been let down by gameplay mechanics, story and bugs. I would love to give this a recommendation but I just can't in its present state. Hopefully over time the game will evolve into a more polished version, and at that time I'll play it through again and amend my review.

reviewText:
I'm really torn about Armikrog.

Sure, it's very charming. The claymation style is beautiful, very well animated, it's really funny at times, and the plot is overall pretty good, with tons of story in the background to find (and by tons, I mean there's a wall - a literal wall - of exposition for you to read at your own devices).

But then, there's the bad. It's really bare bones. No interactions with the environment, no clever uses of items, no inventory at all... There is absolutely nothing to do besides the essential; it's too simplistic for its own good.  Also, it's surprisingly short. I just beat it in one sitting, and there's really nothing to do afterwards.

Also, the audio. Oh boy, it's a bit of a mess. The voice acting seems like it's missing some punch to it; the main character in particular seems like he's just uninterested in everything. And for some reason, his recordings in particular sound really low quality in relation to all other voices. The soundtrack is fantastic, but there are a few bugs that will make the whole game go silent.

But I'd still say to give it a go. It gets frustrating at times, for various reasons, but its charm is undeniable. Just make sure to get it at a discount, because it is NOT worth its full price.

reviewText:
Firstly I'd like to say while this review will seem mostly negative anyone who enjoyed neverhood should buy this game strictly to help support the makers.

Now down to business the graphics at first glance gave me those nostalgia feels all over, but as others have pointed out something felt like it was missing it certainly didn't have the immersive appeal that neverhood nailed. This may be due in part to the music.. what happened there? for 90% of the game there is little to no sound outside of effects, I only really noticed about 4 or 5 songs throughout and with no settings in the menu to adjust the volume levels its a major let down. (dont get me wrong the soundtrack to neverhood was so spot on that my expectations may have been unreasonably high). That being said the sound effects themselves are repetative almost to the point of agitating depending on which section you are in. Story line is also a bit lack luster and paired with puzzles that are quite abstract a lot of the play time comes from wandering around wondering what the hell you missed or forgot to try clicking on.

I have to sum this up by saying its very clear a lot of time and effort went into the making of this but I had high hopes for a longer playthrough and for the length of the wait from conception to release I wasn't sure what to expect but by the time the game is done it lacks a lot of the reward you hope for from a point and click puzzler. I expect most people will be able to wrap this game in under 10 hours with very little replay value.

tl:dr - Great effort but if you are looking for complex inventory built style point and click this game will not be for you, if you are looking for a visually appealing as well as unique p&c then make sure to add this to your list.

reviewText:
Armikrog is a strange vibrant adventure filled with style and plenty of personality. The games visuals are what sells it, from the claymation to the stop motion animation. Armikrog visually is top notch, with a comedic twist but it doesn't stop there. The soundtrack, voicework, of Armikrog is also a treat for the ears. The games intro immediately sets the tone for whats sure to be an entertaining adventure. Now where things begin to get hazy is gameplay and bugs. Armikrog was a game that was delayed a few times and I think it would've benefited from staying in the oven a bit longer. Mostly Armikrog lacks polish, areas like the options menu, interactions with the environment, and lack of inventory make the gameplay feel hollow at times. While I didn't run into many game breaking bugs I did notice some sound issues would occur after cut scenes. It's these types of things that need to be patched out, which I am sure the developer is working on. At the end of the day though I don't think these issues hold the game back from being enjoyed. If you read between the lines you can see that the game is a passion project and it shows. Everything is there as far audio/visuals, all the game needs is a little TLC and polish.

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/3ULO1eyXrxY
I hope you enjoy!

reviewText:
Despite a rough release at launch, this has polished up into a great game.

It's unfortunate that so much negativity descended on this game due to a release that was late, buggy, and missing some features. You'll see a lot of negative reviews here with very short play times here, and they're justified. The initial release had broken music that didn't play most of the time, a static cursor that made it tough to tell what you could interact with, some game-breaking bugs, and other issues that added up to a game that was not as fun as it should be, Almost all of this has now been fixed in the months since launch, and while it could still stand to have a few options and more logical menu design, it's playable in all the important ways.

So let's back up and forget the messy launch and start over. Most of the interest in this game surrounds its connection to The Neverhood, a cult-classic from 1996. Indeed this is the work of the same key staff: Writer/artist Doug Tennapel, animator/designers Ed Schofield and Mike Dietz, and composer Terry S. Taylor. Although there's no connection to the story or characters of The Neverhood, it is in every other way a direct successor, with the same distinctive claymation style, same basic gameplay, and similarly weirdo soundtrack.

To that effect, Armikrog is a smashing success. The backgrounds and characters are more gorgeous than ever, now in glorious high-def and with lighting and shadow not possible in the original. The animation is even better, and it shows that the project leads are best known as animators. The soundtrack, while maybe not quite as memorable or plain-old weird as The Neverhood, is still pretty fantastic, blending eerie sci-fi theramins with Taylor's playful whimsy.

Game design also follows a lot of the same cues, for better or worse. It uses the same, simple one-click interface, and inventory puzzles are of the simple lock-and-key sort, and work automatically if you have the right item. There's also plenty of logic puzzles, which, like Neverhood, often fall into tropes like sliding tiles around, entering in codes, or putting things in sequence. They're not wildly original, but they're balanced well, forcing players to think but rarely escalating to the point of frustration, with the possible exception of a difficult puzzle at the very end of the game.

Most of the game's strengths and flaws are the same as its predecessor, so if you liked The Neverhood, it's easy to recommend Armikrog. The only caveat is that Armikrog is missing the one thing that made The Neverhood stand out most of all: It's originality. The Neverhood defied comparisons by being totally unlike anything before it, while Armikrog is, by very nature of what it is, planted squarely in its predecessor's shadow. It might be a new world and a new story, but almost everything about Armikrog is a call-back to The Neverhood in some way. For most of us, that's exactly why we want to play it, but it also can't quite have the same impact the second time around.

reviewText:
This is probably one of the most difficult reviews I had to write. It's very tough to say whether I recommend this game or not.

Let's start with the positive stuff. The style of the game is unmistakable. As soon as you dive in, the clay animation and the goofiness of the main character sends you right back to the good days of the developer's previous works. Now our character has a sidekick with whom it has extensive interaction throughout the game which seems a pretty good find to me.

The gameplay itself is also very familiar for the fans. Strange mechanisms, weird symbols, looking for the right tip - all of that is back. Some solutions will require working together with the sidekick which definitely brings something new into the game.

The backstory is there, and it is given in separate pieces, just like before. So you uncover all the details as you go. I think it was also a great decision to implement it as stories which language you do not yet understand, so at first you just try to guess what it tries to tell you by looking at the picture.

So why do I doubt whether I should be recommending the game? The main reason is probably that it is simply too damn little. The gameplay time is surprisingly short. I spent about 5 hours in the game, even though I didn't rush anything and was trying to get into the game. That's simply too little. Some people suggested that this could be a demo, and I somewhat agree, it's does not feel like a full game.

The game offers little in terms of the game world as well. In Neverhood we used to have a fairly large world with many locations and free movement between them. In here we only get several locations which are all inside the same castle. We don't get to go outside, the only available mode of transportation is the electric cart.

Same thing can be said about the story. Characters other than the main one and his sidekick get very little development. So when I finished the game, I definitely felt hungry for much more.

Some people here also complained about bugs, but I can't say that's true for me. For the entirety of this game I don't remember being stuck because of the bugs even once. Probably it's because I played the game much later after the launch, but that doesn't change the fact: it's well made by now.

My verdict: yes, you should probably play it. Despite being short, it is well-made and pretty enjoyable. Get it on a sale, and you will have some good time on a weekend. Just one thing you have to keep in mind: don't expect the scale of Neverhood, or you will be very disappointed.

reviewText: This is a great game held back by a few flaws. But I will start with the good things. Awesome claymation art style. Good voice work. Fun to play. Great soundtrack. I only have 2 complaints and they weigh it down pretty heavily. I don't normally mind a game being short but 4 hours is kind of ridiculous for the price especially when you know the core content could be reduced to about 2 hours if you got rid of the time wasters and guessing puzzles. I am a huge fan of the Neverhood, Skull Monkeys, and Earthworm Jim but this game just doesn't seem to reach the greatness of its predecessors.

reviewText:
Refunded the game after encountering incredibly inventive and profound bugs. I always try to look past the little issues, and often have great luck where others suffer glitchy performance. But in Armikrog, every limit and boundary of half-♥♥♥♥♥ have been crossed with gusto.

I backed the game for a token amount, and then bought it for full price, and then - with heavy heart - refunded it. All I know about it from the forums tells me that I've A) seen most of the locations and puzzles in the first half-hour; and B) ran face-first into 3 game-breaking bugs out of at least 6 widely reported.

Independent, free-spirited game development is great. Channeling the worst amateur attitudes (like busting deadlines, then hiring unpaid interns, then (presumably) doing the programming itself on the last scraps of money and time) - is not charming in any way. It's unpleasant, actually. Game design and UI of the short game would be called meh" even in the times of vastly superior Neverhood. Now
