reviewText:
I was looking forward to this game so much, and was very early to chip in to the kickstarter campaign to play what was supposed to be the spiritual successor to the Neverhood, one of my favorite games I've played (Just look left, Klaymen is my frikkin avatar).

But this is not an adventure game, it's a series of arbitrary puzzles. And it completely misses the spirit and atmosphere of its predecessor.  The world is beautiful and the music by Terry Taylor is just as excellent as I had expected. I really wanted to like this game, but it feels forced, the storyline is shallow at best, and most of the world is unresponsive until the moment it can be useful in a puzzle.  See a button? You won't be able to tell if the game is broken or not because you can't even press it until the game allows you to. No response from the characters saying it did nothing. No negative feedback whatsoever.  You're simply not allowed to press it.

I'm going to go play the Neverhood again to quench my thirst for a good claymation adventure.

reviewText:
Short:
Enjoyable experience if you know what you are getting into, but it is not justifiable at the current price point.

Long:
While Armikrog doesn't live up to the Neverhood it is still an enjoyable experience while it lasts. While normally I would come down hard on a game for only being three hours long I will excuse it as I understand that this was likely the extent of what was capable on such an optimistic budget for a claymation game. Claymation is an extremely expensive medium as it requires hundred of hours of work for even a minute of footage, and I realise adjusted for inflation the Neverhood's budget was three times larger.

Thankfully for me I never experienced any bugs during my two playthroughs save for some artifacting on some cutscenes, if I experienced any other bugs I probably would knock a point or two off my score and wouldn't have recommended it. Your results however may vary regarding bugs.

What really irked me about Armikrog was how bland and uninspired most of the puzzles were, I also found the  characters weren't as lively as I expected. Outside of four cutscenes the characters lacked personality and they do not really converse.

While I would still recommend this game it is only a very soft recommendation, and not at the current price point. If you want to experience this title wait for a sale of at least 50%.

Pros:
- Beautiful world and design
- Great soundtrack

Cons:
- Compression issues with cutscenes
- Characters and story aren't very lively beyond very few cutscenes
- Short length
- Mediocre/recycled puzzles

6/10

reviewText: My Playthrough          Youtube Video                 The Review        Oh boy I review another Kickstarter game I supported that really disappointed me. First off let me talk about the things I liked. I love the aesthetic of the game. At a time when claymation games are super rare, it's nice to see one getting this much attention. The soundtrack is really good. Terry Scott Taylor did a good job on the soundtrack.\nNow for the things I didn't like. This game is way too short. You can finish this game in about 2 hours, not worth $25 price tag. The puzzles are too easy and for game which puzzles make up 100% of the gameplay, that is unacceptable. But worse of all the characters and story are so bland. After completing the game I know next to nothing about Tommynaut and Beak-Beak. Which is really sad because one of them dies in the game. This game doesn't try to flesh out the characters at all as their is little to no dialogue between the two or cutscenes. The voices of Michael J. Nelson and Rob Paulsen was wasted in this game. The Story is the greatest failure of this game. The story is so bland and so simple that it can't even hold a candle to The Neverhood's story. And the game ending is so disappointing and is just trying to pave the way for the eventual sequel. This game feels like an incomplete demo of a game and not a full priced game. In the end this game tried to be a spiritual successor to the Neverhood but instead it turned out to be a very mediocre adventure game that did not understand why the Neverhood was so great in the first place.

reviewText:
The Neverhood is back in a more compact form.

Gone are the days of first person wandering around with a silent protagonist. This game is more tightly built, focused entirely on puzzle solving and boy does it have puzzles. It's twice as hard as the first game in my estimation.

Be prepared to write down every symbol you see, or backtrack a lot...in fact, you'll be bactracking regardless :)

The world is expansive and just as spectacular as in the first game. Attention to detail is fantastic.

Missing from the game are the long cutscenes and first person walking that characterized the original. It's a shame, perhaps there were budget constraints. Other than that, the story is fine, similar to the first one, but with more exposition and snippets of dialogue.

Terry Taylor is back and so is the atmosphere. The game sounds and feels quirky and odd, just how it should.

The game feels somewhat shorter than its predecessor, more animations would have been appreciated. But what is there is solid, fun, nostalgic, and definitely challenging. It took me roughly 9 hours to complete it. (with a non frantic pace)

I think fans of the Neverhood will find what they were looking for here.

P.S.: There were a few bugs on launch, hopefully fixed in the following days.

reviewText:
A lot of criticism on this one, so, to be clear:

This game is hard (not hardcore, but pretty hard for a modern audience) with amazing visuals (let's remind that Claymation is one of the hardest form of animation, and they did a brilliant job) and plagued with bugs. They need to fix audio, save states and crashes. All the reviewers made a point saying that is nothing compared to The Neverhood. Yeah.

But.

This game is made with 900.000$, for who doesn't know is a standard/low budget for a game made in Claymation by an indipendent studio, by a little team. An impressive load of work. trust me.

The Neverhood was financed by two major studios in 1996, when game selled so well that even Spielberg invested in the industry (Dreamworks Interactive was founded by him). Huge effort, and a bigger team, but low sales.

So, make another claymotion game is not only an act of courage, but an act of pure love for this forgotten form of art.
You can criticize the result, but pay respect for those who made Armikrog. Because is a visually stunning and good written game.
I hope for a bug fix soon, because Pencil Test Studio deserve better. And i hope for a sequel.

reviewText:
When this game was announced on Kickstarter, I was beyond excited. I almost threw my wallet through my laptop screen. I danced around my room. I moulded my own face out of clay. The game fully exceeded its targets. Then like, two years happened. Great! I thought. The game will be longer! Better! More beautiful! I couldn't wait for The Neverhood's massively intricate backstory, rock-hard puzzles that furthered the story, characters with stories and personalities you could invest in and unique setting and gameplay.

Well, the good news is that the setting and animation live up to that hype. It looks beautiful. The animation is gorgeous. The cutscenes are fabulous. There's really good music and one hell of a lot of humour in this game. There's the beginnings of a really good backstory, too. Unfortunately it just doesn't feel finished. This game started to tell a really good, intricate story and then it just kind of forgot about it and only really honoured that story when it absolutely had to. The villain is terrible. All we know about him is that he has a name and that he knows the protagonist. That's it. No motivation. No personality. No backstory. And the same pretty much goes for our protagonists; He's just a guy. That really disappointed me, even if The Neverhood's ENTIRE WALK THROUGH BOOK was a bit excessive.

It's short, too. Me and Luke clocked up a grand total of 5 hours of this on Steam and it's done. Completed. No more. No reason to replay. No reason to go back and explore. No hidden tidbits. Everything in this game is just there to further the gameplay. Nothing to embellish at all.

And then the gameplay itself is just not that fantastic. Sure there's puzzles but some of them are repeated two or three times. There's no guidance or hints, and the only real way to solve most of them is brute-force and trial-and-error, which really pales in comparison to, say, The Neverhood's mouse maze, or the radio room.  They set the ending up for a PERFECT alternate ending. But we just weren't given the choice. Why? I wanted that choice! It's like they wanted to do it but they just didn't have time. Even though they had more time than they originally asked fo

Overall, I'm glad I only paid £10 for this game, and I wouldn't really recommend anyone spends full price on it. As much as I love the universe it's set in... I wish they'd just been more realistic with their goals and instead of skimping out on this game, set their targets a bit higher and their deadlines longer and made a more complete game from start-to-finish.

reviewText:
*Contains spoilers for the very beginning of the game*

The spiritual successor to The Neverhood. A game that I love and cherished in my childhood for its creativeness, that dark, scarey tone, and bits of comedy. This game however feels lacking in just about all of that. You play as Tommynaut, 1 of 3 brother astronauts that are sent on a planet saving mission to find P-tonium, a source of fuel they rely on. Tommynaut ends up crash landing, and takes shelter in the fortress Armikrog where the game takes place.

Puzzles: The game did not feel as difficult as The Neverhood, but then that may have been because the younger me had trouble with the Neverhoods insane puzzles, but even when I played it recently, the puzzles were still difficult... Armikrog did not have that problem. I had trouble with one puzzle because I overlooked one teeny tiny detail so the answer was incorrect. Aside from that, some puzzles took no time at all, some took no more than 5 minutes, 10 minutes at the VERY most.

Stability: Being Day 1 Release, the game did have some bugs, despite being delayed for the past two months. Nothing game breaking, just annoying. Some sound issues, clipping issues, and a save issue that set me back a few minutes.

Length: Very short. Granted you can only put so much into a point and click adventure/puzzler that takes place in a fortress, I finished this game in about 5 hours. The neverhood took me 6-8 hours last I played it, and I played it straight through with no breaks. Plus the neverhood felt more full, having a much larger world to explore, a 3D point of view, and tons more puzzles. Armikrog recycled 2 seperate puzzles 3-4 times each, and the others were similar in concept.

Music: I couldnt tell you how much I loved the music from the Neverhood, but the music in Armikrog does not live up to that unfortunately. Armikrogs music was good when I could hear it, but the game's bugs often cut the music for me, leaving me with very little noise. The music in the Neverhood was a lot of fun, you even find yourself singing along to the gibberish sometimes, but Armikrogs music was a bit more serious, more mysterious, less entertaining.

Overall: I am honestly disappointed in this game. I DID have fun while playing it, but it just felt too short, too easy, and did not live up to the Neverhood's legacy. If you enjoyed the neverhood, you might still enjoy this game, but dont set your hopes too high.




** END OF GAME SPOILERS**
If there is an expansion (that adds at least 10 hours of gameplay) where we rescue tommynauts other brother after recieving his mayday call, I may reconsider this game, but for now, I could not recommend it. 5 hours on a game that cost me 25$ is not a very good value in my opinion. Maybe I'll come back and replay it and get more of my moneys worth in time, but I cant see it happening any time soon.

reviewText:
Having never played Neverhood I had no nostalgia walking into this. All I knew is that it was a point and click adventure puzzle game made in stop motion, and for what it was it was pretty great. I became aware of the game a few week before it was released on steam and it had my interest. After release I heard that the game suffered from bugs, and I held off buying for a month or so while the patches came in. So coming into this I had a bug free experience that didn't effect my opinion of the game.

Visuals:
The visuals are pretty damn nice looking and the stop motion animations are of some damn good quality. Nothing looks off other than a few minor parts of the game where the green screen effect wasn't 100% removed from the objects in the world, but honestly its so minor I noticed it only on 2 things.

Gameplay:
Pretty standard as far as a point and click goes, but they did manage to streamline the whole clicking aspect. By this I mean you have no accessable inventory to grab items from and try and use them on different things. If you have the right object you'll be able to interact with it and progress. This elminates the trouble of use-everything-on-everything-until-something-happens" part of PnC games that eventually happens. This makes the game more puzzle focused in terms of problem solving and finding the right clues to the puzzle and working with the puzzle with the knowledge you have.

I will say however that one puzzle isn't very clear in what you are needing to do
date: and for some reason has the puzzle solution given after you've already cleared the puzzle. However the solution is visible in the room its in
recommended: just not very obvious.\n\nAll in all this was a prtty solid game for what it was

reviewText:
Was waiting for this game since I am a big fan of the Neverhood. I was disappointed mainly because of issues and bugs that are not supposed to be there since the game is not on Early Access. I got a cWTB (conditional walkthrough break) and I pretty much stopped there since I need to start from the beginning over again. I have seen other people with similar issues.

But that is not the only thing, I hate that there is nothing that helps the player to understand what can be interact with. I mean I dont want a big highlight or something, but at least make it different than the rest of the non interacting objects. Give them attract. In the Neverhood, the rooms are pretty much empty so you know what can be interacted with and in the Neverhood, the mouse cursor change when there is a direction to take and in the Neverhood the mouse cursor fit with the rest of the artstyle. Okay thats a small complaint, but what about a default window cursor now that pop-in cause it just does not fit. Or you click too much on the side and you lose control of the game since windows take on.

I wanted to ignore them, but each time something bad come up and I just cant ignore it anymore. There is also some design choice that are just bad. The baby puzzle is.....is.. really bad, the baby sound is annoying (Yoshi's Island only flaw is that you?) and the wait, oh GOD THE WAIT for the puzzle music to play. BTW speaking of music, they just stop playing randomly and then there is no music at all, even ambient.

I have issues with the animation and the music, little things that pill-up more on top of the main problems.
The music is not as funky and out of this world as I was expecting, its a little let down for me + the fact that it just stop randomly does not help so I cannot listen to it. They did not polish little things like TommyNaut entering door from the front, where you can see it not aligned with the door and the animation is stiff. His walkcycle was kind of disappointing, I have difficulty to read is personalty. I can just see him as a couragous space traveller. The personality of the main guy is important because you need to like to be him kind of. If I compare it as the main guy in the Neverhood, where you can clearly see that he is born like an old child, he does not even know the difference between bad and good and when he walks, he just dont give a ♥♥♥♥ (probably one of the best walkcycle Iv seen in a game). It sound maybe weird that I talk about walkcycle or the mouse cursor, but they are important in a game where you see them all the time.

Its sad a little too that you see the world at the beginning, but you stay in the Armikrog fortress for the rest of the game without exploring the place more. I like how there is animation, dialogues and extra elements to interact (window) in the first room of the game, but after that those things that you find in a finish product are gone. I was hopping for some extra jokes or interaction, hell there is a part where the bird can ♥♥♥♥ on you, was a good place to insert a funny thing, but no !

Is there good things, yes, it is fu/$?ing stop motion claymation making the artstyle awesome. A really beautiful adventure. Not only pretty, but the design shape of things that are twisted. its less dark and lonely than the Neverhood.

They keep the same simple point and click no inventory gameplay, I dont have complaint with that. However the puzzles already started repeating themselve when I stopped.

To conclude, Armikrog seems unfinish and full of issues giving a feel that there was few QA work. Waiting can maybe fix most of the annoyances if the devs are still working on it. Sorry Doug but for the moment I cannot recommand it :<

reviewText:
Excelent return of a classic style of adventure games.

People are never happy. One minute they will praise the unforgiving dificulty of Dark Souls after they die the 1000th time, the next one they will complain about a wonderful indie title that the developers animated by hand, because the cursor has issues.

Armikrog features exquisite handcrafted clay model graphics and animations, has tremendeous voice action (Michael J Nelson of Rifftrax and MST3K) and an out of this world soundtrack by Terry Scott Taylor. It also has hard-as-nails puzzles with no hints for Real Hardcore Gamers (TM).

Enjoy the game and support the developers so in the future they can bring out more experimental and leftfield work like this.

reviewText:
I'm editing my review into sections so hopefully it will be more helpful.

Graphics: 8/10
The game has a unique look, the characters are creative and the backgrounds are interesting to look at. The animations are well done.

Story: 4/10
Very basic cliche story, not very creative or inspired.

Puzzles: 4/10
Very easy requiring little thought. There's maybe one puzzle that took me a little longer to solve but the rest are really really easy.

Gameplay: 4/10
Lots of backtracking, no feeling of reward after completing puzzles because they are so easy.

Overall: 5/10

Other thoughts:

- Seems like all the creativity went into the art design, story is generic and cliche, unspired.
- Overall got bored halfway through with the backtracking, lack of challenge, and unengaging story. The only motivating factor for me to continue was to see the rest of the cool clay level designs and characters.
- Not worth the asking price of $30 CAD. There are better point and clicks at that price, you could even buy 3 for the price of this game. From my experience with the game I would pay $5 or $10.

reviewText:
tl;dr
It's a lot more like The Neverhood than you know.
-----------------------------------------------------

If a person has downvoted the game for not being enough like The Neverhood, they probably hadn't played the game in a long time. Truth is, it follows a lot of the same beats. The puzzles are maddening. There's a lot of boring transition time. Notepads and basic doodling skills are required. The plot doesn't really make an appearance until the very end. All of these things make up Armikrog, too.

You can finish the game in just a few hours with a walkthrough. If you're playing it that way, it helps to think of Armikrog as less of a game and more of an interactive picturebook.

Despite a buggy release, it doesn't deserve nearly the amount of unfiltered hate it's been getting. The Neverhood wasn't exactly a Day One critical success either. It took a few years. That said, don't buy it on Steam. Get it on GOG.com instead. You get a DRM-free copy and extras like music and artwork. Burn it to disc or save it to a memory stick, then pull it out in twenty-five years. You'll be happy you did.

reviewText: Supported the project via crowdfunding. Today is 5 of october and I already finished the game... (Installed yesterday). The game is quite cool, with smell of old Neverhood, however: it is REALLY TOO SHORT, TOO EASY. I've spent just 5 hours to finish the game. Don't really like that characters now talk. The last thing i REALLY DON'T LIKE, is that you are having similar tasks / quests multiple times. Most of the game you make your baby stop crying, or travel via cart to some places, or solve the round-puzzle (which is quite easy). If you make screenshot on each location via steam or your system (I played in Ubuntu), you can then open screenshots on second desktop or via steam and take a look at them to see the solutions. WAAAAY TO EASY. The music is okay but the game is still short for a good soundtrack. Also, there seems to be not 100% made from plasticine. Sad, sad, sad. It's 30% of Neverhood. However, I would recommend this game as long as noone make quests like this now...

reviewText:
If you loved the neverhood as much as I did growing up with it, then I have no doubt in my mind that you want to buy this.

If you love point and click adventure puzzle games, there's no doubt in my mind you'll want to buy this.

BUT

My first playthrough (not on steam) took me 5 and a half hours, COULD be considered short by some, but not by me.
My second playthrough (on steam) Took me just over an hour, THAT could be considered short by a lot of people, even me (Neverhood knowing the puzzles took maybe 2 hours)
It doesn't have the wacky cutscenes that The Neverhood had and the main villain isn't set up enough, but I believe that the nostalgia of a new game by TenNapel and Co. can make up for it.

Kind of sequelteasing as well, maybe if Armikrog is successful we'll start getting a series? I certainly hope so.

All in all, I recommend the game for people who either loved The Neverhood or just love Puzzle point and clicks in general.

reviewText:
Armikrog is a smaller indie version of The Neverhood. It had a much smaller budget to start with, and no game studio to keep the development funded twice as long as originally intended, which unfortunately happened. When you come to terms with that, it is actually a fun little game worth playing.

$25 is too expensive, though, because the playing time will probably not exceed 5 hours and the content is not that dense. Fine for Kickstarter purposes, but after release, the price should (and probably will have to, eventually) reflect that.

PRAISE
+ I mostly appreciate the visuals, which are expertly animated, beautifully crafted and Mike Dietz with Ed Schofield really showed us that they still got it.
+ The same goes for the music by Terry Taylor, which could be a little more prominent in the game.
+ There are some original, pretty and fun puzzles.

RANT
- The scripting and the story are the weakest point. The plot is explained in 4 pencil-animated sequences, including the intro, and the ending is just a plain deus-ex-machina. The villain wants to get the child, eliminates its mother and father, who then help you to save the child. Unfortunately, that's not a dumbed-down version, but pretty close to how the story is actually presented.
- All of the characters are very superficially treated and undeveloped. The authors threw away the main advantage of having two protagonists, who only act in the few cutscenes there are.
- Bugs that are annoying, but at least in my experience, they were not game-breaking.

It seems to me that the developers, facing the fixed budget, must have focused on the most expensive and essential thing to do: the hand-crafted, hand-animated visuals. You cannot have such a game without that. The biggest problem is that this part comes last, after all the story and all the pencil-testing are finished. Rolling this big boulder before them must have been pretty daunting, and the game looks like they needed to plan much less than what they hoped for, out of fear that there would not be enough money to finish.

I think that this game is cursed with both not appealing to the mainstream enough" for any game studio to fund it
recommended: which is a shame. My verdict is that you should buy it on a sale
hoursPlayed: because it is still a showcase of rare talents and there will be very few
voteText: if any other games like it."

reviewText:
Armikrog is a fun point and click adventure in a unique world
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d9c71gKV6hQ
The game is a spiritual successor to The Neverhood. Meaning it plays the same, and has a very similar feel to it, however doesn't share any characters or world.

Armikrog has some really awesome Claymation skills behind it, and some of the environments really are a joy to look at. One thing that I felt fell short, was the fact that sometimes digital effects are used. This takes you out of the immersion. One of the things that made The Neverhood look so real, was the fact that everything WAS real. The lighting bounced off the clay naturally. Most of it is traditional clay, but you'll catch the occasional digital effect.

The game has some funny characters, dialogue and situations, which will get a bit of a chuckle out of you. A few times it also got me laughing pretty hard.

The puzzles are the perfect difficulty in my opinion. Enough to make you scratch your head from time to time, but not impossible. My main gripe with these is there's one puzzle that you will do multiple times, with increasing difficulty and little variety. It's not awful, but I would have preferred if it was left out.

Similarly to The Neverhood, the soundtrack is composed by Terry Taylor. The music is nowhere near as amazing and catchy as it was in The Neverhood, because it's not as crazy. That's not saying the music is bad, it's well composed and a joy to listen to, but easily forgettable when compared to the soundtrack of the Neverhood.

Overall, it's still a very fun game (Although a tad bit short). Not as good as The Neverhood, but still a unique and enjoyable experience!

reviewText: This game has gotten very mixed reception, and I can see why.  It's very much a sequel to the Neverhood in the thematic sense, like Phantasmagoria 2 or the Final Fantasy games as it uses many of the same themes and structure.  Like the Neverhood, it's claymation, the story never really goes much of anywhere until near the end, the backstory is told through animated line art, there's a giant wall of text with more optional backstory and lots of puzzles in a relatively small structure.  Thankfully there aren't many ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t puzzles like in the Neverhood, but the tradeoff is they're mostly pretty easy.  I thought a few were clever though.  It's also shorter, but feels like it would have dragged on if it went on for too much longer.  The ending isn't the best, but that's just another comparison to the Neverhood.\n\nArmikrog made me feel nostalgic.  It made me feel like I was in the 90s again, and that makes it special.  If you aren't the kind of person who likes 90s adventure games, then it will seem dated in many ways.  I give it a recommendation, but a careful one.

reviewText:
Armikrog uses claymation with some small cartoon animations thrown in there. It’s important to note that the claymation has an incredibly raw look to it, which I assume is intentional, like old-school Wallace & Gromit or The Trap Door.

Unlike most point and click adventures, there’s no real inventory management as most items are more or less given to you upon completion of the puzzles, which are the meat of the adventure. And even better, they are all rather intuitive logic puzzles. When you put your mind to it, they are all possible to complete without trawling through google for walkthroughs.

The story itself is simple in construct and while you have to back-track every now and then, the back-trackings flows naturally and often requires to approach the same place from a different route. The characters lack a bit of personality, and as such, any real motivations behind their actions and the events that take place. But I didn’t find this too disconcerting as the main focus is the puzzles.

My only real criticism for the game is its steep price for a max of two hours (give or take) of gameplay. Even this criticism I’m reserved in making as I’m aware of the amount of time and effort that goes into making claymation films (I’ve watched those Wallace and Gromit behind-the-scenes films). Then again, this was a kickstarter with close to a million dollars invested into it.

Despite all this, still worth the play and an examplery point and click adventure.

I couldn't resist the aesthetic and I liked the tone, feel & score but the puzzles fell pretty flat due to symbol hunting & recalling and the occasional pixel hunt. The story was super odd. Maybe they went for a mysterious or minimalist vibe but it comes off as half-baked. Interesting to see Jon Heder (Napoleon Dynamite) play Vaugnaut.

There's a momentous amount of text inscribed across a large wall in the game which contained a far more complete story, which although provides some context for the events and settings in the game, is hugely disconnected from the gameplay. I enjoyed reading it nonetheless despite some obvious pandering to kickstarter funders. Game looked great on my 2560x1080.

Eh/10 (I've never played Neverhood Chronicles if that makes a difference)

reviewText:
The Neverhood is one of my all time favorite games and holds a very dear place in my nostalgic gaming heart. I can understand the want for others to hold Armikrog to the standard of its spritual predecessor, but I'd like to steer clear of a direct comparison as I believe it's a tad unfair to do so. After all, The Neverhood was a big budget title published by Dreamworks Interactive, green lit by Spielberg himself, and released at full game price. For the lack of this financial support and a smaller team Armikrog is a bit shorter and a smaller scale.

Visuals:
Pros: Armikrog has creative character models and envoronments that made me feel in a sense that I was picking up right where The Neverhood left off. I can't enough of these claymation worlds. Armikrog is quite colorful and real treat to look at. If I had to give Armikrog anything over The Neverhood, it would be the be expanded color pallette and extra care that was put into the detail of the rooms overall. The animation and cutscenes (though few) were top notch. I played it on a 55inch tv at 1920x1080 and it looked great.
Cons:  I get this feeling though that more in the way of cutscenes (not to mention dialogue and immersive elements) but may have been cut for budget or time. I would like to have seen more easter eggs similar to the monster scene when you look through the window repeatedly. Another odd thing is that there is no lip movement from the characters outside of cutscenes.

Sound:
Pros: The music of Terry Scott Taylor is top notch as usuall, though I would like to have heard a couple more memorable tracks. The sound effects are acceptable.
Cons: I feel like not including more dialogue between our 2 heroes was a big missed opportunity. Even just a funny exchange about each room you enter would have been a huge improvement.

Gameplay:
Pros: Fairly straight forward and liked the addition of a second character (Beak Beak!). There were atleast 3 big puzzles that I found to be quite unique and creative.
Cons: I feel like the overall difficulty on some of the puzzles could have been kicked up a notch. Also thought it would be nice to include a bit more complexity to how you use BeakBeak. For instance maybe he could eat other things that give him other abilities you could add to the puzzles. Perhaps swimming or digging.

Story:
Pros: Overall I loved the story that was told here. Where The Neverhood had an entire biblical chronical written, Armikrog offers some of its lore in a different way. You couldtell that a lot of time was spent on the hieroglyphs and the alien language that you can for the most part transalte your self. When the games translates it later and the full back story is known, I couldn'thelp but be reminded of the Willy tapes.
Cons: I would like to have had a bit more back story on Tommy, Beak Beak, and the main villain. Again this could have been easily fixed by more dialogue exchange to deliver some exposition. The ending/wrap could have been a bit longer and tad more rewarding.

Bugs: I didn't experience any and really do believe some of the reports are people losing their patience or maybe (perhaps never had) their old school adventure gaming skin. If the lever you have doesn't work, than it is the wrong lever. If a button or control panel doesn't work, than you prob haven't activated it. Just Sayin...

Armikrog is not as good as The Neverhood. In someways it was problably incapable of being that, but there are flaws they could have without a doubt avoided. Overall though I enjoyed the experience and would buy another game if they made one.

7.5/10

reviewText:
This was one of the few games I backed on Kickstarter so I was really looking forward to this.

Unfortunately, the game ended up being very short, very buggy and the puzzles in this game become very repetitive the further you get. The music and the claymation style is wonderful, but the faults stick out like a sore thumb.

Unfortunately, I was never able to finish this game because I saved at a certain late part of the game and when I reload that save I'm stuck and can't get out. I refuse to play through the game all the way from the beginning just to see the ending.

Do not buy this game.

reviewText:
It is a nice game. Not great, not even good. It is just nice. Paying the full price is not acceptable, And I'm sorry I didn't wait for a sale to buy it.
I had so many expectations for this game, I loved playing The Neverhood so much, but Armikrog seems so pale in comparison. It's not bad at all, I had some fun hours playing it, but I wanted so much more..

I really loved the way they put some references to The Neverhood, like robot bill on the wall, or the history writings in the wall, or even the cannon , those little details made me smile.

The graphics and the music were gorgeous, really great, but it felt like 80% of the resources for the game were spent on them. The important part about this game was suposed to be the puzzles. I expected that feeling, when you have collected so many clues you have no idea where  to use, and as you progress in the game you find some riddles you have the answer, and find some more clues, and in the end it all FITS it all makes sense. When you are being told a story but there is some fulcral detail you discover in the end that makes you suddenly understand the hole game. I am really sad I didn't have that, the game felt so empty. Most of the clues you knew what they were for not that much later into the game. You never really had to turn back to solve a puzzle that has the answer further ahead.

It was really linear and really short.The puzzles were not that hard, and I was expecting something much more complicated, more conected, more complex. The game was short, the story had so much potential to be developed and it wasn't. But it wasn't, because to have a satisfactory story the game would have to be SO much longer than it was. They probably didn't have the funds or the time, and that is verry sad indeed, because this game was full of potential.

Somehow the development team missed something indescribable that made The Neverhood so loved. The verry essence of the game, what made it special (besides the claymation, of course) is missing in armikrog. The contents of the game were shallow and underdeveloped and it's really unfortunate it turned out like this.

Nevertheless, it is still worth playing, and worth buying, and I'm sure the development team made the best they could with waht they had. A good game, for those who had no previous expectations for it.

reviewText:
As a fan of The Neverhood, when Armikrog was announced I was genuinely excited for the spiritual successor.

Cons:
* Pretty short. Completed in under 3 hours. Same length as Neverhood, but would have loved it to be a bit longer

Pros:
* Funny as hell
* Really great visuals
* Awesome soundtrack
* Puzzles are hard but fair
* Just god damn fun

I paid full retail $20 preorder for the game, and to be honest for 3 hours gameplay thats asking a lot - and im glad it delivered. If you're new to Dougs games, then maybe hold off until its a tad cheaper - or pick up the Neverhood on GOG and realise why this is worth $20.

reviewText: Puzzles aside, Armikrog is still a good game. It's not perfect, and it can be frustrating at times, but if you're willing to overlook its shortcomings you're bound to find something to enjoy here. For me it was the claymation art. Stunning. The voice acting, what little there was, is top notch. And the story, while I barely understood most of it due to the strange alien language spoken by the octopi during their tales (it would have been great to have some subtitles there) the ending alone is worth trudging through the landscapes to reach your goal. It does leave more questions than answers and being rather short (what adventure isn't?) it doesn't adequately bring closure to the quest. Almost like it was the first part of a series.\n\nhttp://www.kickstartadventure.com/home/armikrog-review/

reviewText:
Armikrog is the spiritual successor to The Neverhood[en.wikipedia.org], an adorable point-and-click adventure game from 1996 made entirely out of clay. Armikrog is made by much of the original Neverhood team, including lead designer Doug TenNapel and wacky musician Terry S. Taylor. It’s a lot like The Neverhood, and if you haven’t played that, it’s similar in gameplay to Myst.

So there’s good and bad. The good is pretty much all of the game design, story, art and music. It’s fantastic. More on that in a bit.

The bad is mostly technical. As you will see from many of these Steam reviews, this game is buggy. Like, really buggy. Little bugs, big bugs. A missing animation here, a difficult-to-find click-spot there, a game-breaking save corrupting bug every once in awhile. Save often, with a new name every time, because you never know how far back you’ll have to load because your game is in an (accidentally) unwinnable state. The good news is that the team have patched the game four times in the past few months and fixed many of the bugs and issues. There are still some left, but they are working on it.

So, looking past that, what’s the game like? As with its predecessor, Armikrog is a claymation game, and that’s just cool. In 1996, the cost and difficulty of producing a clay game vs a 3D computer graphics game was probably about even. In 2015, the tools and technology for 3D are so advanced that it’s the obvious choice. The team absolutely chose the hard road here and it’s worth it --- the soul of this game is in the fact that everything is literally hand-crafted. It feels so unique. Unlike The Neverhood, this game also uses bits of other materials like fake fur, paper, metal, and yes, an accordion.

So you basically control this clay guy called Tommynaut who looks suspiciously like Klaymen, and can switch between him and his blind talking dog, Beak Beak. Each character has his own unique abilities: Tommynaut can pick up and use items and complex interfaces, while Beak Beak can go through small holes to reach new locations. So you have to use both characters in tandem to solve puzzles. The most annoying part is having to switch to the other character for non-obvious reasons (most common: if there is a knee-height switch, it won’t even register as an object for Tommy; you have to switch to Beaky and have him press it). There is also a distinct lack of feedback when you try the wrong thing, or the right thing at the wrong time. The puzzles are pretty simple and intuitive, and mostly based around learning a strange alphabet of symbols. Have a pen and paper handy and write down any clues you find, and you should be fine.

The game is missing the first-person outdoor areas from The Neverhood. You pretty much never go outside, but it does have the track/cart sections connecting the different buildings together.

It’s a little short --- took me about 5 hours. The characters are likeable. The story is simple but compelling and worth seeing through to the end. All up, this is an undervalued gem, that lives up to the original game, and that I would wholeheartedly recommend, save for the many UI and technical issues.

reviewText:
Note: I played this game about 6 months after release, and for me the launch bugs experienced by many people were ironed out - it was a very smooth experience.

This game is not for everyone. I think if you get frustrated by incredibly obscure puzzles, look elsewhere. Fortunately there are hints for the puzzles dotted around the game, but they in themselves are obscure. You will be challenged. You will need perserverance. I'm not the best puzzler around either, so I had to check on the ol' internet walkthrough a few times, but I'm so used to that it really didn't bother me.

Perhaps those who are not familiar with Doug TenNapel's earlier works (Neverhood, Earthworm Jim, Kog-Head & Meatus) will struggle to enjoy Armikrog. You almost need to know what to expect to really 'get it'. To quote TenNapel in an interview, Armikrog is 'iconoclastic'. It really is. And to me that's what really makes it enjoyable.

While the limited plot makes not a huge amount of sense, the stop-motion claymation visuals are so off-the-wall in a typical TenNapel way that makes the game impossible not to be endearing.

Finishing the game left me wanting more, in a way Earthworm Jim provided through sequels, a TV show and action figures. Armikrog may not reach those lofty heights, but it stirred that strange feeling of nostalgia all the same.

reviewText:
As a game in its own right, this is moderately entertaining, but as a successor to The Neverhood it really is terrible.  The Neverhood managed to feel like a whole world that you moved around, a world with an interesting and mysterious backstory, whereas this comes across as a series of disconnected rooms, one puzzle after the next, with a predictable, weak, and very short, story underpinning it.  There's also not a lot of originality in the puzzles, the same three or four get repeated several times with slightly different colours/icons/sounds/etc

From a production standpoint the animation/clay is nicely done, however the voice acting is appalling, both in script and in recording quality.

The weird music in the Neverhood was always a favourite of mine, and when i saw the same guy was doing the score for this i had high hopes, but with the wild variations in volume, the buggy sound and the speed with which you can complete each section meant i didn't really notice it :\n
At 4 hours of playtime i feel a bit short-changed.  It's not really a game you would replay, so it works out pretty expensive if i look at it from a cash-per-hour-of-fun perspective!

Seems pretty buggy too, for such a technically simple game, particularly the sound.  Several times it just cuts out entirely until you quit and reload.  A couple of the puzzles don't seem to store their state properly, for instance it's possible to retrieve certain objects multiple times.  Nothing that broke the gameplay, fortunately, although it did make me nervous.  When you're stuck with a puzzle it's all too easy to wonder if the game's just broken.

Overall, i'm a bit dissappointed. Had this been made by a couple of students as a college project then i'd say this is awesome"
date: but as an offering from a professional team
recommended: it's embaressingly poor.\n\nI'd recommend this game when it's down to a couple of quid in the bargain basket
hoursPlayed: but until then
voteText: just not worth it.  Find a copy of the original Neverhood instead :)"

reviewText:
From the same producers of the Neverhood and those who have worked on productions such as Wall-e, Alladin and Eathworm Jim and can be found here... http://pencilteststudios.com/

While their resume is truly impressive, unfortunately it serves to no credit of this production called 'Armikrog'. By no means is this a BAD production, but when you compare it to the truly magical masterpieces such as 'The Neverhood' this unfortunately just stands sluggishly in it's shadows.

Since the developers no longer own licensing rights to the Neverhood and a evergrowing cult fan base were constantly demanding a similar stimulating imaginitive claymation adventure, some of those responsible in the previous game went on to make this one in the hope that they could copy the magic of the first one. Here is where it fizzles out into a pile of playdoh.

I can't help but think that the developers cut some serious corners thinking that they would get away with it or that it would simply pay off. IT DIDN'T!

So what makes this one rather limp wristed in comparison to its predecessor? First of all there is a serious lack of facial expressive shennanigans on the characters, therefore the animations seem rather dull in comparison to the Neverhood. Isn't facial expressions what makes fast paced animations like Roger Rabbit so memorable? While we mention fast pace, there isn't a real lot of that. Most of the backgrounds seem rather the same. The modes of travel along the cliff scaling clay cart was tediously long.

The music was constantly cutting in and out at random moments, producing long moments of deadly silence. There seemed to be a real lack of a musical score. While there was some momentful songs in the game like 'I wrote a song with your name in it', they were very few and far between.

Several places you could not only make the sound glitch by clicking on cut animations more than once, but you could also click your character off the cliff in various places where you were not suppose to go making your character spasm violently like he has been possessed.

The puzzles seemed to very similar to one another and not as imaginitive or as respectfully designed as it was in the Neverhood. While they built a long elaborate story to go with this game, one that is comparable to the size of the Bible just like they did in the Neverhood, but because of the lack of connection that most people will have with both characters and the uninspiring backgrounds and creatures, not many will even bother to read it.

One of their biggest mistakes was taking out the 3D dimensional view which was in the Neverhood and which made you feel like you were part of the alien landscape exploring it.

In short all this production did for me is long even more for the magic of 'the Neverhood'. Unfortunately I have serious doubts if they will ever make it. Why? I liken it to the 'Flying High' movies produced by the Zucker brothers which everyone loves. When Zucker brothers split each one making their own production, each one tried to produce something of the same high calibre magic. Some were close, but ultimately they all failed. It seems the true magic of the production came from the whole spectacular group working together. Maybe thats going to be  the same case here. Certain creative people missing, and so this will never be of the same rich level of gaming treasure history.

Am I exagerating how great 'Neverhood' was? Well let me put it this way. If you still own 'the Neverhood' in it's original box you can now sell it for around $150.00. I very much doubt in 20 years you would even be able to buy lunch with what you sell Armikrog for...

Close guys, but no cigar...

reviewText:
First of all I funded this game on Kickstarter, and i am happy i did.
This game is a piece of art!
And with that you have to accept that it is not perfect. after all no one would care that the Mona Lisa is hung crooked. or had no true function. its still art.

There are bugs, that may or may not get fixed over time in patches.

Basically:
The game is BEAUTIFUL!!!
The story... could stand more details and polish.

Είναι πραγματικά κρίμα για ένα παιχνίδι που λάμπει από άποψης animation, voice acting και προσωπικότητας να χαντακώνεται έτσι από τεχνικής φύσεως προβλήματα κι από ελλείψεις που θα μπορούσαν εύκολα να έχουν αποφευχθεί.

It's a real pity that a promising game like Armikrog, which is shining in terms of animation, voice acting and persona, falls so short due to various bugs, sound problems, puzzle repetition and serious design flaws such as lack of hotspots and corresponding indicator. It could be a much better game but it obviously wasn't ready for launch at this time.

reviewText:
If you've liked The Neverhood, this game is for you.

This is an old school point and click adventure game, with all the good and the bad, and although I really enjoyed it, it also reminded me of why the genre is dead today.


The good:

+ Amazing clay-graphics and beautiful not-clay animation (in some cutscenes).
+ Great Terry S. Taylor soundtrack and great voice acting.
+ Deep and immersing story, especially if you read the in-game huge text-wall.
+ Balanced not-too-hard puzzles that you can solve if you sit and think about them for a while.
+ For a Kickstarter game that funded 950,000$, It's pretty long. If you know what you're doing in both games, I believe it's as long as The Neverhood is, although in The Neverhood the puzzles were much harder, so that would make the game much longer on a first playthrough.


The less good:

- Some pixel hunting and tricky hot-spots.
- Too much backtracking with no shortcuts.
- Puzzles are easier than The Neverhood, and sometimes not as original.
- Less animations compared to The Neverhood and smaller world. It FEELS like a Kickstarter game.
- You can't view your inventory, so it's hard to keep track on items you have on you or not. I solved two puzzles by mistake before using an item that should've given me a hint about one of them, and although I didn't need to use it later, it really confused me to hold an item that I couldn't use.
- Some repetitive puzzles that feel like an annoying mini-game you have to solve.
- A little expensive for what you get in my opinion.

And one last thing: you will need a paper and a pen when playing this, a LOT. I pressed the PrintScreen key and copied pictures to MSPaint every time there was some weird shape in the background, so I would remember small details for later puzzles. I enjoyed it, but you might not. It's that kind of puzzle game.

If you've enjoyed The Neverhood, it really is as close as you can get today, as long as the genre is dead. I felt at home.


Kickstarter games and expectations:

I've bought The Neverhood when it was out, at the end of 1996, and played it for hours. I didn't have an internet connection back then, and finding out how to solve hard puzzles was freaking impossible. We had to ask gaming magazines for help, and I still remember how happy I was when I finally solved the BOBBY puzzle.

Kickstarter is a great platform that helps small companies skip" big companies

reviewText:
Armikrog is a beautiful point-and-click puzzle/adventure game. It starts off with a wonderful animated intro sequence and good music, followed by an exciting and enjoyable claymation cinematic that kicks off the game. You are pumped to get started, and for the first few minutes, it's very promising.

After that, though, the game starts to fall apart (gameplay wise).

Ignoring the missing menu text that was fixed in a timely fashion, the game seems unpolished, and far from ready to release. I had to restart the game from nealy the beginning after discovering that you could not overwrite saved games. The game did not tell you this, because you get no feedback when you press save to know that you have actually saved it.
Bugs and frustrating moments leave you with the question Is this supposed to be like this

reviewText:
The good:- The visuals are amazing. I really love the claymation and how they mixed that up with other materials like cardboard or fabric to make the surroundings visually attractive.
- The story is well-rounded and clear, you learn more about the background and purpose while playing and the end-scene wraps it all up nicely so you end the game with a feelgood experience.
- The puzzles. If you're an experienced puzzle-game type you might feel different about this but as I generally suck at puzzles I really enjoyed these. Some were easy, others a bit more challenging but never frustrating. Having played the Neverhood ages ago, I knew I had to keep a notebook nearby to keep track of symbols and hints. Who knows, you might need them later on.
- The humor. Sometimes a bit goofy but I had a smile on my face while playing and laughed at certain scenes when I expected something huge to happen and it actually turned out to be completely different.
- The music. I'm going to be humming the name song for days.

The not-so-good (yet?):- Some of the graphic details have an unfinished feel, but there was only one room where I really felt annoyed by it. They 'stretched' an item in a really obvious and ugly way and the interaction with that item was sloppy as well (it got kinda seethrough when moving it). That might have been a time or budget-related thing but I hope they'll fix it.
- The gameplay is mostly smooth but I got stuck during my first attempt of finishing the game and there was no other option but to start a new game. Also: I get the feeling some doors that are supposed to be closed, only to open after solving a puzzle can now be walked through without solving. (ofc. I still solved the puzzles...you never know what you might need it for later)
- As much as I understand claymation takes ages to make, the game is on the short side. Right now, I don't know if there are enough easter-eggs and little details to make me want to explore the game again, especially since the puzzles don't change and once you discover how they all work it takes away some of the fun.

My conclusion:I really loved playing Armikrog even though there are still things they need to work on. It is a feelgood game, and I really enjoyed exploring, solving puzzles, discovering new things. The 'world' is limited but funny and quirky and leaves me wanting to see more. Right now, I wouldn't play the game again but finishing the game was a fun journey. I really hope Pencil Test fixes the issues reported (especially the gamebreaking ones but it couldn't hurt finishing some of the graphic/stretching issues) and when they do, I'll play the game again to see how it was intended to be. If you're willing to 'forgive' Pencil Test for releasing a game that still could use some work: go ahead and buy.

reviewText: I have been waiting to play Armikrog for 2 years. It got released earlier today but I had stuff to do. So I downloaded it and went about my day. I got home today, made dinner and played through it all in one sitting. I have a lot of mixed emotions as an avid point and click fan, and for those who know me.. a die hard Doug TenNapel/Earthworm Jim/The Neverhood fan. On one hand, the game was absolutely stunning and a testament to how innovative and creative a team of developers can be even with limited time and resources. The game was very well designed and left little to be desired artistically. On the other hand, the game is still bug ridden which is to be expected considering its launch day. From a AAA publisher/dev team I would have expected more but seeing as it is an indie game I will cut it some slack. But by far the biggest issues I had was that the puzzles were way to easy and the story was barely there which in turn results in the game being extremely short. My first playthrough took about 3 hours. It feels like this was rushed. Altogether I did enjoy this game, but I wish it was a bit longer. Just my opinion if anyone is interested in purchasing it. 7/10

reviewText:
I, too, backed this on the Kickstarted having loved the Neverhood and let me tell you I was very hyped to see a similar game made done.

Although I recommend you to play it, I don't find €25 an adequate price.

It is very clear that 99% of the budged was spent on the creative part. In a way, that is a good thing - you get to see amazing art, the clay motion and voice acting is rather amazing and certainly top of the genre.

But! The programming is very poor. My very first experience with the game was a menu without labels on buttons (fixed now) because I am on non-US system. It makes you wonder how (if at all) was it tested? Save/Load is on Options menu for whatever reason. Sometimes, subtitles don't match the speech sounds (I am not talking minor variations, I am talking totally different lines).

And the playing time is rather short. I had completed it in about 3 to 4 hours.

Bottom line - if you liked The Neverhood, you are going to like the art. You are also going to like the story *SPOILER ALERT* but only after you progress very far in the game because until then, the storytelling elements are spoken in gibberish. *SPOILER ALERT END* However, the story feels less immersive, somehow you feel more like an outside observer than actual part of what is happening inside the game.

reviewText:
As a Neverhood fan and a backer, I do recommend this game. It was good fun, nicely constructed, and has some fun music.

I can't tell what a person who hadn't played The Neverhood would think of it, but from my perspective it comes across as an overly derivative sequel. Most of the plot was copied over, but without the justifications which made it interesting. Instead of walking around and appreciating a cute clay world, admiring it inbetween puzzles, you just spend half your time in a vehicle. It lacks The Neverhood's wacky humour which made the claymation so much fun.

I was hoping for an adventure game with more complexity and depth, maybe something Monkey Island like. I also hoped it would be longer. And I find the price I backed it for to be fitting, but maybe not the one it's up for on Steam for how long it took to play. Each area has the same set of puzzles to repeat multiple times as you travel from one to the next, instead of an open exploration type thing. I did run into a couple of bugs as well.

It's possible that knowing the style it inherited from The Neverhood beforehand put a damper on the experience because it wasn't all new and quirky. Plus I basically already knew the plot. I still have to say I recommend it though - despite being a shallow version of its predecessor and everything else, it's still the type of game I want to see more of, and it was a cute, nostalgic, if bland, experience.

reviewText:
Armikrog is a classic-styled pont and click adventure featuring plenty of clever puzzles, fiendish brainteasers, wacky character designs and beautiful stop-motion animation. The soundtrack varies from being atmospheric to playful. Unlike many other point-and-click games, Armikrog features NO dialogue trees. Much of the puzzles are based off of finding secret symbols and codes to use elsewhere. Be sure to take notes with a pen and paper while adventuring!

As a fan of point and click games from companies like Lucasarts and Telltale, Armikrog is a breath of fresh air, as its lack of dialogue trees and its use of symbol-focused puzzles give it a unique gameplay experience. You'll love to explore the mysterious tower and learn about its tragic history.

The voice acting is excellent. Michael J. Nelson and Rob Paulson deliver excellent performances as the two lead characters.

Unfourtuanetly, there are a few bugs to be found within the game. I have experienced animation glitches whenever I grab onto a squid's tentacles, and there is one area where Beak Beak the dog needs to jump on a switch. It doesn't work properly, as no matter how many times I click on the switch, he simply WON'T sit on it. However, these bugs do not detract from the experience.

If you are a fan of point-and-click games and/or stop motion animation, Armikrog should be a no-brainer for you. Buy it now and head off to adventure!

85/100

reviewText:
I was afraid to go ahead with my purchase of this game when I saw the many negative reviews I saw, but in the end I'm so happy I didn't listen!
I love The Neverhood, as well as Skullmonkeys, so much.  I was so happy to see that this team decided to make another game after all these years.

In a lot of the comments I saw that people were not pleased with Armikrog; that it wasn't like The Neverhood. I can't tell if these people are just bitter, or what.  Now I haven't actually beaten the game yet, but from what I've played, it DEFINITELY feels like The Neverhood.  Of course it's not going to be exactly the same, but it's got that spirit.
I haven't encountered any game-breaking bugs (perhaps because of the patches?) but I do see some slip ups here and there programming-wise I suppose (for example, when climbing the tentacles or riding in the little buggy) but nothing that's made me want to stop playing.  The puzzles are a bit challenging, but you do end up going back and forth a lot and clicking a lot of stuff, but isn't that the point?

The only thing that really bothers me is the fact that sometimes when the characters are speaking in-game outside of cutscenes, their mouths don't move.  It's not a big deal, just a little off-putting to me I guess?

Please, if you're a fan, give this game a chance.  It definitely gave me the feels.

reviewText:
Billed as the spiritual successor to 1996's The Neverhood, Armikrog for the most part follows through on that promise.

Despite being a point and click adventure game in the classic style, Armikrog makes a number of streamlines to the genre design. For starters, your movement is much faster than the plodding steps of the Neverhood, which makes backtracking relatively painless in this game. Inventory management is automatic, and you'll only be carrying three items at most at any time. The puzzles are pretty standard fare though, sticking to an approachable increasing difficulty structure, and they don't reach the esoteric variety that was present in Neverhood.

Playing with pen and paper is recommended. It's how Neverhood worked, and it adds a lot of fun to a playthrough to jot stuff down and reference your notes when doing puzzles. There are a number of pictographs scattered around the titular Armikrog so it's best to write them down.

Like Neverhood Armikrog's story is fairy slim, the most exposition you'll get is in the cheesy opening song. Unfortunately the lack of a proper finale event left me a little wanting for one last puzzle. Thankfully there's voice acting to flesh out the wider cast, and Tommynaut and Beak Beak make a very charming duo.

Armikrog works with a much wider range of materials than Neverhood's clay to shape it's enviornments, but unfortunately the difference in production value shows. There's no first person view segments, and the budget doesn't allow for a 6 minute long cutscene. This game was crowdfunded for just under a million dollars, but the cost of stop motion adds up, and the game cuts corners in a number of ways. That said finding an enviornmental detail that catches your eye or seeing one of the protagonist's numerous idle animations can bring a smile.

Terry Scott Taylor return to do the soundtrack, and while the ingame audio isn't as in-your-face as the iconic tunes from the Neverhood, some like the aforementioned intro theme of the game have a lot of charm.

Unfortunately this game had a troubled development. A number of delays and a not-great game design philosophy (hey, Earthworm Jim was panned for being a game developed by artists) hamper the initial release of the game. While my four hour playthrough was absent of any major issues, there were a number of minor visual flaws I noticed during my experience.

If you can justify paying the price tag for the stop motion visuals, Armikrog is a nice experience that stands in contrast to That Other Point and Click Revival Game.

reviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed this game and regret not knowing about the kickstarter as I bet there was some cool reward tiers.  As a big fan of The Neverhood game and puzzle/adventure games in the similar vein, I was ecstatic that the creators came out with Armikrog.  The surreal environments and the random obscure monsters and aliens were all excellent.  The puzzles were decently challenging.  The controls were odd at first but once I got a handle of switching characters the game was enjoyable.  Where most games follow in a linear fashion and then eventually open up for exploration, this game basically stayed linear.  You really only needed to backtrack if you didn't take careful notes.  I do feel that some of the puzzles were easier than they could have been, but if they were any harder I think the little kids out there would just gripe and complain.  I did not follow a guide or walkthrough to complete the game and I feel that the game itself was pretty straight foward.  This sounds negative but honestly it was so refreshing to enjoy this wacky world.  I am a big fan of the clay environments with the added flair of fuzz and fur.  I hope there more games coming and I do feel thirsty for more.

reviewText:
So I beat the game, read everything on that giant wall of text, rewatched every tentacle-elevator story cut scene, you know - really got into all the nooks and crannys.

And my general impression is - eh, it's alright.

There are tons and tons of escape the room" puzzle games out there with much harder to figure out puzzles that you can play for free. There are tons and tons of games out there that are more immersive in the world they create that you can play for the same price as this. And there are games out there that put those two elements together better than this does.

The reason I still recommend it is because it's creators trying to do something that most game makers don't do anymore - take chances. I'm honestly not upset in the slightest that this game isn't as good as was hyped

reviewText:
-I was gifted this game right when it came out, so it was a little buggy when I was first playing, but I dropped a bug report and the Devs fixed the issues within a day or two.
-The game CAN be very long, depending on how good you are at solving the puzzles. Some of them were ridiculously hard for me, and some came fairly quickly.
-It's a typical point and click puzzle adventure game, like Samorost 1 and 2, and Machinarium. I love this game genre, so I naturally really loved Armikrog.
-I think by far my favotire part of the game was the use of claymation, stop motion, and photography for it's characters and backgrounds. Amazingly beautiful and cool, really isn't done enough in games. I think the only other game I can recall that looked that way was Skull Monkeys. The art style was incredibly cool and inspirational.

reviewText:
While not as whimsical as I remember The Neverhood being, I had a wonderful 5 hours with Armikrog (played the first 2 outside of Steam via back download).  It had a lot of neat ideas and a seemingly simplified mechanical system without inventory management.

The difficulty was perfect for me as I'm generally terrible at point and click adventure games.  The puzzles were fun, straight forward, and didn't have you retreading the entire game in search of some random illogical thing (looking at you Broken Age).

Spoiler: There's a set up for a sequel at the end, which I'd love to see happen some day.

reviewText:
Had only one bug that prevented me from finishing the game, in the very last room. I speedran through the whole game (1.5 hours) from start in order to get a fresh play-through and everything went off without a hitch.

Well, I thought the music was good. I really liked the story wall. The animations were nice. Had some jarring volume differences between the normal game and the FMVs. Wish there was a volume control for the game. Puzzles were about moderate difficulty. Much easier than Myst or Riven.

Comparison to The Neverhood - Armikrog does not equal The Neverhood. While cleaner, the characters were less likeable, there was less humor, the puzzles were easier and there was a lot less Terry Taylor making wierd stuff up on guitar.

All said, I still recommend it. I was a backer, I waited through all of the delays and had a game breaking bug. I might be crazy, but I can't hate Armikrog.

reviewText:
If you want to enjoy this game try your best NOT to compare it with Neverhood.
Yes, same creators, same style, clay, bla-bla-bla, enjoy the picture, but  DO NOT compare!  If you do, you'll ruin the experience and will probably be a bit disappointed.
Personally, I enjoyed the game a lot.

PROs:
+ clay animation combined with more materials and other animation styles looks awesome
+ I acctually had to draw on paper to solve some puzzles
+ new language inside the game, not just symbols but actual voicinng   When those octopi-things are telling Beak-Beak the story first they do it in that language
+ a little drama touch was nice
+ cute characters and monsters
+ references to Neverhood  Remember robot Bill (with teddy bear) from Neverhood? You'll see some of those. And you'll have to fire a cannon one more time

CONs:
- rather short
- not very funny, although it had some potential
- not many difficult puzzles, most of which were just getting repetetive
- feels a bit unfinshed, unpolished, there's much more that could be done to make the game more compex and more interesting, I think developers probably should have taken more time, but add those small detailes (like clay cursor or moving lips or just more phrases from characters) that would be very apreciated by everyone, and it wouldn't feel so raw

Still, I think the game is worth playng. Of course, you're probably interested in it because of the Neverhood, but don't expect it to be as good and varied, and then you'll enjoy it.

reviewText:
Finished the game in about 3 hours, but remember portal can be beat rather easily in around 2.

Being a longtime fan of Doug TenNapel and mike Dietz and the rest of the crew, I was really stoked to hear that this game was happening. I was so excited when it got its Kickstarter goal! But I can’t really help but feel this is just a budget version of their Neverhood game. (Skullmonkeys was awesome but kind of a different beast)

It mostly felt lacking for me, because I had high expectations. It wasn’t really all that funny like the other games and it almost feels like it is a little rushed. There is a part of the track in the game where it leads to where you might be able to go if you came from the other way but there isn’t really a way to get over there that I have found, and it is not a part of the game as far as completing it goes.

There were a few glitches I came across like teleporting transportation and in one building I could just enter it without doing the key puzzle. (The door was visually closed but you could just walk through it.)

The game could have done with some beta testing or at least more if it had it.

My biggest hope is this does well enough that they are able to continue the story and hopefully do a better job in the next game, which I hope they are planning.

I just felt the game lacked the polish of the games that came before it. It almost feels like a fan made tribute to said games. But that could simply be the difference of the amount of people involved and the lack of AAA title money.
I don’t feel there was enough dialogue or really just enough game in general.

Terry Scott Taylor was also rather underutilized… the only real song I felt was wonderful and up to snuff with the other games was the Kickstarter song with your name in it. This isn’t to say that the music is bad, it is still good and enjoyable, but like the rest of the game, it just isn’t enough.

I almost feel like they spent too much time on animation and not enough time on fleshing out the humor or story. It was all just very linear.

BUT, I want more. I want so much more of this game, from this game. The oddball humor and just weirdness of it all is sorely missed in today’s videogames. Please buy this and support these awesome people in hopes they can make another bigger and better game.

reviewText:
If you have not played The Neverhood, then Armikrog would be a great adventure for you.

I had high expectations for this game because The Neverhood was incredible, but Armikrog does not even compare to The Neverhood. The Neverhood had a lot more difficult puzzles and cutscenes, and the story had so much more depth and memorable characters. It even had an alternate ending.

I would say the developers have succeeded in creating a unique and visually stimulating art game, however, the gameplay was too simple, quick, and even frustrating at times. It was also overpriced.

However, I may be biased since I have played the Neverhood. If you have not played it, then Armikrog would be a blast and that is why I recommend it.

reviewText:
Be aware the game is buggy at the time of release, but nevertheless I managed to play it all the way through to the end with minimal problems.

So, nearly 20 years since The Neverhood launched and became my favorite game of all time. Is this the worthy successor that we've waited for all this time since then? Yes and no.

In the art department, Armikrog absolutely delivers. Gorgeous claymation environments and characters with all of the surreal atmosphere that we've come to expect from its predecessor, and in gloriously crisp HD resolution to boot. The new Terry Taylor soundtrack is nothing short of fantastic, with awe-inspiring themes and the composer's trademark quirkiness and eccentricity. The puzzles are challenging, but never unfair; there's plenty of clues to be found and even when I did get stuck, I found the solution no problem after taking a little break. The story is interesting as it develops, and full of wacky humor, with decent performances from Mike Nelson and Rob Paulsen to boot.

On the other hand, the game offers no real surprises for long-time Neverhood fans, as the overall set-up is basically the same. Several puzzles get repeated throughout, and although they steadily increase in difficulty, it feels like the designers were taking the easy way out. Some important elements can be tricky to spot, and even when clicking on something, the game won't always immediately respond or even give you any sort of helpful feedback, which makes things needlessly frustrating. Finally, the game is really short, though nevertheless doesn't outstay its welcome and ends on a satisfying note.

In conclusion, while this game isn't everything we may have hoped for, it's still a must-play for any Neverhood fans, and highly recommended to newcomers who aren't afraid to try something offbeat and wacky that won't take them long to beat. Thanks, Doug TenNapel. You made me feel young again.

reviewText:
In a preview in June 2015, I wrote that this game has a very unique feel that’s bound to attract plenty of gamers, but wondered whether it would have any material to keep them interested and voiced concerns about it being a case of ‘style over substance’. I also stated: “If the developers now focus their efforts on developing the gameplay and establish Armikrog as a title in its own right away from The Neverhood, we could potentially have something quite lovely on our hands.”

Sadly it doesn’t feel as if this happened. Despite a few delays, the game feels as if it would have benefitted from even more time and budget to polish up the clay-work so the quality at the end was the same standard as the beginning – as well as more testing to iron out the silly bugs. The gameplay is oversimplified, the characters have limited personalities, the puzzles are repetitive and have no drive, and the world of Spiro 5 and its fortress are flat and empty.

It’s the waste of potential that spoils it the most and I can imagine many of the Kickstarter backers coming away disappointed. Perhaps the developers were relying on fans of The Neverhood and their collective nostalgia to see them through and make the release a success, but this isn’t the spiritual successor they’re looking for.

A full review of Armikrog can be found here:
http://1001up.com/2015/12/07/review-armikrog/

reviewText:
+ Quirky art style
+ Beak beak

- Too short.  Plot had no time to develop before it was over.
- Puzzles too simple, and only serve to make you spend time walking back and forth between rooms.  One of the last puzzles requires you to backtrack the entire of Amikrog.
- Many puzzles only test your ability to take notes.
- Many puzzles are more quickly solved with trial and error.
- Half of the items you pick up in the game are levers for activating the next door.
- A bit unpolished in a few areas.  There was some strange reverb during the beginning sequence and some videos.

reviewText: Don't get me wrong: it's really good, but it's extremely short. I just can't recommend it for its relatively high cost, and it's sort of sad because I think the high cost was caused by its art style. It's a claymation art style and it's used extremely effectively and it's very smooth, and that's probably where much of the budget went into instead of being towards the amount of substance. I think that this game's development is one of those rare examples where the quantity of the game ruines the quality of it. It's sad to say this, because I really wanted to like this game since it had so much potential, but it's simply not worth getting. Maybe it could've worked if it were released at the asking price and then continued via episodic releases.

reviewText: The trailers makes it look like a lot happens in this game. Unfortunately, that's not the case. Despite how beautiful the claymation aesthetic is (major kudos to the creators on that), I found this game to be very boring. It's quiet (as in, little-to-no sound for most of the game), the environments are very static (excepting the very few things you can pick up/use), and there's very little interaction between the characters. And even though the world seems rich in the trailers, in the game things are very devoid of life, and not in a well-done-lifeless-planet kind of way.\n\nI don't regret backing this game on kickstarter, because I think more games with a unique aesthetic need to hit the marketplace. Doesn't stop this game from being a yawn-fest, though. Sorry, guys.

reviewText: Having played The Neverhood as a kid, I was really excited to check this game out, even after it got mixed reviews after being released - c'mon, it couldn't be this bad, right? Little did I know, it *is* bad. Probably not the worst thing I've played, but close. The overall concept is great, the character design is great, but the game feels like it was abandoned half-way through. One of the puzzles doesn't even give you hints on solving it until you enter the area it unlocks, which makes absolutely no sense. The price is what makes me even angrier you'd expect something a lot better for this much.
