reviewText:
I need to preface this review with the fact that I didn’t finish this game, and it’s not because I hated it, far from it; it’s because there are a lot of puzzles in this game that take a while to figure out, and I only received the review copy a day before release. I have a lot of other reviews to write, so unfortunately, I just didn’t have time. I’ll say then, take this review with a huge freaking pinch of salt, and do not base your purchasing decision only on my review. That said, I see no reason to not give it some coverage, and maybe you’ll get a feel for the overall game.

So the unique, although not entirely unique, draw to the game is the fact it’s a stop-motion point and click adventure. I don’t think I’m wrong in saying it’s been done before, but it’s pretty sweet nonetheless. I liked the visuals in a creepy kind of way, and I think they captured the adventure theme that fits stop-motion so well, pretty nicely.

As a game it starts to get a little muddier. It’s a point and click adventure, and it’s pretty typical in that way with it really just being about solving puzzles. Though, unlike Broken Age part 1 and the pseudo-point-and-click adventures from Telltale, the puzzles are pretty tough. I never solved any of the more complicated ones, but I’m gonna guess  you’ll need your pen and paper.

I was a little disappointed, honestly, by the voice acting from the main character; his side-kick is pretty good, but I found the voice on the main guy just didn’t really work. It’s also brought down even more by pretty uninteresting dialogue; it was hit and miss for me, there was pretty funny jokes in there, but I found myself groaning a lot too. It’ll really depend on your sense of humour. Aside from that the story seemed pretty unique and I was certainly intrigued as to what was going on. I mean, let’s be honest, the entire premise is bat ♥♥♥♥ insane. You’re like, an astronaut who crash landed and ended up in ruins? Eh, I guess if you boil it down it’s pretty simple.

I also love the cinematics. I went in kinda thinking the whole game was gonna like that but it’s not really. The stop-motion feels relatively not-noticeable outside of the cutscenes, which is a shame. It doesn’t really feel like stop-motion when you're not in a cinematic. Like, a lot of the animations are done like a regular game, 60fps, usual stuff. It’s a shame more of the in-game stuff isn’t in stop-motion (Looking at the making of" video now

reviewText:
5/10: Surreal style and nostalgia can be fun, but with nearly two decades having passed since The Neverhood, the limited content, obtuse logic, and backtracking undermine the impact of this point-and-click game.

Admittedly I backed this due to the nostalgic memory of enjoying Earthworm Jim, and to a lesser extent the Neverhood. Armikrog is unfortunately similar to Neverhood though, with odd puzzles, mechanical annoyances, and limited content detracting from a unique style and a lighthearted story.

As with most point-and-click games, the key frustration (not challenge) of this game is context confusion. Despite the absence of the genres combine inventory items" logic problems
date: the surreal style of Armikrog and utter absence of contextual dialogue exacerbates the issue of figuring out whether something is not working because you don't have the right thing or because the wrong character is interacting with it. For a specific example
recommended: low buttons can ONLY be opened by Beak-beak
hoursPlayed: rather than by Tommynaut bending over slightly. Combined with the long delays incurred by repeated backtracking and revisiting rooms as you look for potential pickups and clues that may have been overlooked
voteText: Armikrog is a perfect storm of point-and-click mechanics problems.\n\nStylistically

commentsCount: but here's how to make sense of the story for those who are playing (potential SPOILERS):\n- What you see at the start is just the setup to explain why Tommynaut and Beak-beak are there.\n- In the second building

column18: and becomes understandable to Tommynaut at the end of the game. You will have to visit each one again to finish the game anyway.\n\nUpon its conclusion
column19: Armikrog left me feeling underwhelmed. Despite a decent story and creative visual style that borders on Seussian

reviewText:
I almost didn't buy Armikrog, because of all the negative reviews, but I'm glad I did!

Steam tells me I took 5 hours to complete the game, and it did feel a bit short, but that's about the only bad thing I have to say about Armikrog.

I played it on linux, and I didn't come across a single bug or glitch in the entire game, so I have no idea what people are going on about. And a non-modified mouse pointer doesn't come near being a problem for me. I don't think I would have even noticed it, if every review I had read before hadn't blasted the game because of it. Seriously? The mouse pointer?

I loved Neverhood, so I bought this game because I wanted to experience more of the same, but perhaps with higher resolution graphics... And that is exactly what I got.

reviewText:
The only thing good about this game is the first room.

After you leave the first room, you won't encounter any more humor or claymated cutscenes, instead you will have to solve... no, not puzzles because those are recycled 3 times each so they're boring instead of challenging. You will have to solve another kind of puzzle, which is navigating your way around game breaking bugs.

Save often because you will load at least twice because you can and will get stuck with no way to continue. That is, if you aren't playing on a 4:3 screen because then it's impossible to pass some screens at all.

You will also have to ignore pre-alpha quality of the game engine: animations not working, dialogs not audible, subtitles appearing when no one is speaking, but not shown when there's speech, certain hot spots randomly not working so you need to leave a room and come back, stuff like that.

The game was released over a year past schedule, by putting together scraps and gluing them together. You will notice dialog was just test sounds sent in by various people and they never re-recorded in a studio. You will see a missing box monster being stretched. If you've watched trailers, you will notice several rooms didn't make it to the game, as well as at least two cutscenes.

So the game puts you in a whacky place but is never funny after intro+first room (which was done before kickstarter campaign, before actual team was assembled and killed the mood). So the puzzles are easy but recycled to the point of not just boring but irritating you. So the game takes 2 hours if you've played point-and-click adventures before. All bad news for a game asking €25, but most of us would probably forget that, on the account that claymation games are so rare and must be hard/costly to make. But the bugs are unforgivable.

The gameplay bugs are really easy to fix (some photoshopping here and there, some hot spot resizing, making the music actually play sometimes). Same goes for all the typos on the wall of text, can't you just paste that into a spell checker?

You know, stuff like that adds insult to the injury.

I wouldn't pay €5 for this if I knew.

reviewText: By no means a terrible game, but I, like a lot of people, had set my expectations up a little too high for this project. Go figure. Everyone thought for sure this was going to be the next Neverhood game. The graphics are really good and the puzzles are decent enough, but many of the mechanics come across as dated and even glitchy at times. The cursor doesn't change to show you where you can click and some of the puzzles have no ryhme or reason to them. I thought Armikrog could at least keep me occupied for ten or so hours, but it turned out to only last a mere 5 hours for my first playthrough, and apparently other people beat it even quicker. This is especially dissapointing after having just finished the Deponia trilogy; three superior point & click games. If you're morbidly curious and want to play this game just for the heck of it, do so while its on a steep discount. Its not worth the full price.

reviewText:
Expecting a Neverhood experience will leave you disappointed, but taking the game as a standalone experience will give you nostalgia of what it was like to game nearly two decades ago. Admittedly, the release is not without many glitches, some of which I can understand, some of which I cannot fathom how a programmer can miss; but if you're looking to scratch your head for a few hours, then Armikrog is worth the money.

I do have a few criticisms for the developers:

The puzzles are repetitive and many lack ingenuity. For example, to enter one of the first doors in the game, you must solve a simple slider puzzle. Eventually, you encounter two more doors where the slider puzzle is the key, each one having some additional tricks to confuse you, but it's still the same concept. Similar with the baby mobile game - the audio and sequences to match get a bit tricky, but it's still the same puzzle over and over. And then there's the sliding block monster puzzles...

The puzzles are intuitive, but the exploration is not. There was no outstanding visual clue that I needed to speak to the Octopi while playing BeakBeak in order for me to progress - this in turn made me struggle to power the generator to activate the lift to find the final glyph for one of the first puzzles. It also took me longer than I'd like to admit to even realize that the first Octopus lift was multi-leveled. Later on, when you feed BeakBeak a bug that allows him to fly, it's not clear that you have to click above him to get him to sprout wings first. In the same area, there's no visual clue showing that you have to click on the background etching in the wall (and not the button next to it) for you to move forward.

Glitches and frustrations galore - you can enter doors without solving the slider puzzles (again, a simple programming mistake). The railcars will always bounce on a switch, which makes traveling to another screen frustrating. Sometimes the audio will cut out after a cutscene. Sometimes you cannot pick up the octopus drop if you leave the screen and then come back for it.

Lastly, the character development could be improved immensely. When I played The Neverhood, I listened to snippets of Willy's story throughout the adventure and, although never interacting with him, I grew fond for the character. Klayman in the neverhood was a silent protagonist with childhood curiosity, which made him relatable when you're exploring a world you know nothing about. Tommynaut's and BeakBeak's personalities do not fit for an adventure-game, and their stoic behavior makes it difficult to feel a personal connection with the characters.

Regardless of the negativity of the above comments, Armikrog is a place I enjoyed exploring, and definitely hope to see more from this studio in the future!

reviewText:
There's not much to say except that Armikrog is really a worthy successor to The Neverhood.
The asthetics and design are exactly what you would expect, and I won't be going into any detail about it, as that would be spoiler territory.

As far as introducing new players to this kind of game, I feel that the puzzles are not overly cryptic and they were quite simple to figure out for me. Admittedly, there are a few that made me scratch my head for a while.

It should also be noted that as of the writing of this, the game has a few language issues and some clipping issues, though I trust that they should be fixed very soon.

Definietly recommended, if you like point-and-click games and/or you really loved The Neverhood as did I.
Great job Pencil Test Studios!

reviewText:
The only thing good about this game is the first room.

After you leave the first room, you won't encounter any more humor or claymated cutscenes, instead you will have to solve... no, not puzzles because those are recycled 3 times each so they're boring instead of challenging. You will have to solve another kind of puzzle, which is navigating your way around game breaking bugs.

Save often because you will load at least twice because you can and will get stuck with no way to continue. That is, if you aren't playing on a 4:3 screen because then it's impossible to pass some screens at all.

You will also have to ignore pre-alpha quality of the game engine: animations not working, dialogs not audible, subtitles appearing when no one is speaking, but not shown when there's speech, certain hot spots randomly not working so you need to leave a room and come back, stuff like that.

The game was released over a year past schedule, by putting together scraps and gluing them together. You will notice dialog was just test sounds sent in by various people and they never re-recorded in a studio. You will see a missing box monster being stretched. If you've watched trailers, you will notice several rooms didn't make it to the game, as well as at least two cutscenes.

So the game puts you in a whacky place but is never funny after intro+first room (which was done before kickstarter campaign, before actual team was assembled and killed the mood). So the puzzles are easy but recycled to the point of not just boring but irritating you. So the game takes 2 hours if you've played point-and-click adventures before. All bad news for a game asking €25, but most of us would probably forget that, on the account that claymation games are so rare and must be hard/costly to make. But the bugs are unforgivable.

The gameplay bugs are really easy to fix (some photoshopping here and there, some hot spot resizing, making the music actually play sometimes). Same goes for all the typos on the wall of text, can't you just paste that into a spell checker?

You know, stuff like that adds insult to the injury.

I wouldn't pay €5 for this if I knew.

reviewText:
There are some major bugs early on, which required me to restart the game 3 or 4 times.

The puzzles are somewhat hit-or-miss: some of them are well-designed and fun to solve. Some of them are straight-up annoying (I'm mainly referring to the lullaby puzzles) and just detract from the game's flow.

I enjoyed the claymation animations, though during the sequences where you use the tentacles to move vertically, I hoped for an actual animation and not just a photoshop-like shift.

For a ~3 hour game (likely +1 hour if you decide to read the giant wall of history text), I felt like they could've simply used a modern save screen rather than the DOS-esque one. I understand that The Neverhood came out in the 90s, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't update your interface.

reviewText:
I kickstarted this game as a fan of Doug TenNapel and a fan of alternative graphic styles, such as claymation, cell shading, etc. I always liked his alternative worlds and particularly liked EarthWorm Jim.

Overall, the game is difficult and incomplete; the menu system, lack of view-able inventory, lack of ability to see what is interact-able or not, makes you feel like you are playing a prototype or beta.

As other reviewers have written, some of the puzzles aren't really puzzles and some of the interactions are awkward.
For example: there's a button and you try and click on it nothing happens, no cursor change, nothing. Is this button something you can't interact with? A button that's locked for now to be unlocked later? Nope. You just need your dog to click it with his tail. Really? My dumb dog can press that button with his tail but I can't bend down and press it?

Making it so that both characters could press the button would have been more realistic and if there is a situation where one character has to press a button while the other manipulates something, let me figure out that by having the wrong person press it, seeing the change in the world and what needs to happen, and adjusting accordingly.

In the end, it feels like they massively underestimated the cost and time required to produce this game. I feel that they intended to release something much grander but ran out of time and money.

If you are an absolute claymation or point-and-click fan, pick it up when it is on sale. Otherwise, I don't recommend it.

One last comment: I didn't have any of the technical issues that some other users have reported, on the current version of the game.

reviewText:
I can forgive that it's short due to budget, or that it's buggy, or that the variety of music lacks, or even that there is zero story. But I really, really can't forgive that they cheaped way out on visuals and feeling.
On itself it might have been fine, but sadly we were promised a game in the spirit of the Neverhood, which this so obviously is not. But even as a basic adventure time game it's pretty 'meh'.
The entire game is in the trailer (which is heartbreakingly deceiving).

At the start I felt excited to exlpore this new world. Sadly after literally 1 minute of intro, you'll be stuck with approx. 2 hours of walking around in half-animated, barely filled 1-colour rooms with no dialogue.  That's the game. Walking from the same room to the same room to do the exact same puzzles.
On top of that it seems that the only reason the main character(s) can talk is so they wouldn't have to animate their emotions. The characters have close to no personal traits (yet clayman did, without talking. Funny huh?), and the 'world' feel frustratingly small.

Do you remember those oh wow!" "haha" "that's cool!" feelings with the Neverhood? Or how sad you felt for robot bill? Or how well written the story on those tapes was? The excitement of finding a new one? You will find none of that in this game.

I did still
recommended: enjoy the claymation and the art style a lot (although this is hard to find
hoursPlayed: considering 3/4 is regular animation or random plasic props). I read the bad reviews and I still bought it
voteText: and I don't regret buying it (though the price should have been 10 dollars).\n\nTo summarise: this is a 2/3 hour game that feels wáy too long to complete. That says all in my opinion."

Over all I would say its a great start but far far far from the original Neverhood. It took me weeks to beat the Neverhood. I have completed Armikrog in less than 6 hours."

reviewText:
It's hard for me to give negative review for this game, as I was really hyped for it and I'm a big fan of Neverhood. I even backed it up on Kickstarter, this is how I believed that it would be spiritual successor to the Neverhood. However, there is a big gap between them.

TL;DR Game doesn't live up to modern game standards, it doesn't even live up to the Neverhood. It's buggy, shallow and short. When bugs are fixed and it's on sale 75%, buy it. It's good, just not for this money.

1. Quality
On the release date there is a lot of bugs. I was lucky most of them didn't happened to me, but still I got some. I had sound turn off partially (I heard only background music) for no reason, which made me restart the game. I had small animation glitches here and there. Some areas (like big green button in first section of the game) had poorly made clickable area, I always have to try multiple times before game understands I want to click this button. Cursor is plain system cursor, if you played the Neverhood, you would expect something better than this.

I've seen other people having more serious glitches, like character not being able to go to certain areas, or missing menu labels (seriously?!), or being able to get to area you should not be able to reach and getting stuck there. I still believe those bugs will be fixed in near future, but for now, you might get stuck because of that.

Speaking of quality - why on earth would you put save/load in options" instead of main menu?

2. Graphics
Well

I was looking forward to this, I really was. I was hoping the delays meant we were getting something extremely polished, but aparently not. I've only played for 20 minutes, and already I've encountered a multitude of bugs and just plain lazy design choices that greatly hindered the experience.

- Couldn't press a button, left the room and came back in, button suddenly worked.

- No animation when the characters are talking, don't even think this is a bug, but it's awfuly jarring.

- Pulling lever caused door to replay opening animation, this is something straight out of a crappy flash game, like seriously, am I supposed to believe nobody noticed this stuff?

- Entered and exited a room multiple times without any music, it suddenly started playing the fourth time I entered.

- No contextual cursors, have fun guessing!

Refunded

reviewText: When I first heard that the creators of The Neverhood were about to make a game similar to The Neverhood and use the same old creating techniques and mechanics I was so happy, mainly because The Neverhood was a part of my childhood, I remember playing the game with my dad and my brother multiple times, it was one of those game I will remember forever. So now after a few years after I backed this project on kickstarer it finally came out and I finally played it. Well, what can I say, I had a blast, some of the puzzles were a bit repetitive but the feel of nostalgia and the great soundtrack simply made my day, I beat the game in two sittings today and it was just great. Lately I haven't played much adventure games because they aren't that good nowadays, I enjoy simple adventures and armikrog. is an adventure game exactly for me, but don't be fooled some of the puzzles require quite a lot of thinking and a lot of backtracking if you aren't the type that takes notes of every little symbol and the area it was in. The game is great though, but I have to say it didn't surpass the neverhood for a few reasons, one of these reasons are the already mentioned repetitive puzzles and some of the bugs I came across, like some of the areas not unlocking if you solved the puzzle or the sound cutting off and so on. Overall I would say it was a decent bang for a buck, I backed the game for 20 dollars so I only got a digital copy but Iam satisfied, the developers delivered what they promised, the lenght is not an issue for me but I would like a little more of those sweet and funny cutscenes. Maybe next time. Thanks Ed, Mike and Doug for everything and mainly for the great games that are The Neverhood and Armikrog. ! Thank You !

reviewText:
As a kickstarter supporter of this game, writing this review saddens me...

I just finished the game, and while it was fun, it simply is far too short.  I have a mere 6.2 hours on Steam's playime for the game, and I left the game running several times while I took a breaks (to eat, etc), meaning it was probably more like 5 hours of actually playing.  There were no SUPER challenging puzzles...  I simply remember Neverhood being much longer, and much more challenging, and by comparison, Armikrog is subpar.

If you're picking it up on the cheap for 90% off on some Steam sale months from now, yeah, totally worth it, but it's just not worth full price.

reviewText:
Boring, repetitive, linear, short and disappointing.

Some might say that this is an early review, when the game is still undergoing some bug fixes. However, this review has nothing to do with it. I want to reflect on how the actual game felt, what it was like and whether it was enjoyable (bugs aside). Here’s a brief summary:

Pros:
- Beautifully crafted game with its unique style of animation and “clay feel”.

Cons:
- The game is very linear and short;
- “Adventuring” through the game follows a boring pattern;
- Almost no puzzle variety;
- Puzzles feel completely repetitive – same ones are being used over and over again with slightly increased difficulty.

I am a Neverhood fan. When I stumbled on Armikrog by a complete accident – I can’t tell you how thrilled I was. Needless to say, I was watching the game as it was getting closer to release and grabbed a copy as soon as it was available. I never imagined myself to be in this position and say this – but I regret this purchase.

After much wait, hype and anticipation – now that I finished it all I can say about this game is that it turned out to be a disappointment. As much as I wanted and mentally pushed myself to enjoy it (and it did make me smile and marvel at the fantastic style of the game a few times) – I just couldn’t.

The game simply felt boring. It’s very linear. Once you finish an area, you hop on a transport and move on to the next, where you are presented with an entry puzzle. Once you’re done with that and the area, you are presented with an exit puzzle – and you move on in the same fashion. Only to experience THE SAME challenges again (just a slightly more difficult versions) in the next zone. There are some puzzles that are unique and fun (as you need to gather and keep track of the clues), but overall you can’t help but feel let down.

The whole game you just follow a boring pattern and keep doing the same things over and over again, with the only highlight being an environment around you.

I thank the artists for making the game as any Neverhood fan would expect it to be and look like, but the progression and puzzles complety ruin the whole experience. This game could've been much more in my opinion, and it saddens me to say that.

Don’t want to sound negative and you should experience everything for yourself and form your own opinion, but I would not recommend this game.
voteText: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Giant disappointment.

1,000,000 dollars and you can't even make a custom cursor with some sort of user feedback to I can tell what the hell I'm able to interact with? Save/load in the options menu? Who the hell designed this?  First and only Kickstarter disappointment so far. I would say I got, maybe, 5 dollars of enjoyment out of this, but that would be stretching it. The worst part is how clear it is that the potential for this to be a quality game is beneath the surface lacking the effort and polish necessary to make it something actually good.

And the audio recordings, wtf is up with the voices, they sound like they were recorded in a metal barrel thats been chucked down a ravine, muddy and total trash, I do amateur recordings with <200 dollar setups which are higher quality, seriously low budget sounded.

So many ♥♥♥♥ poor decisions, no inventory you just pick up an item and mash around randomly, with no signifier to tell you what you can and can't click on, no dialogue or clue when you click on something you can, can't, or can't yet interact with, and no idea whether its a static object or an actual part of the game/puzzle.  Most puzzle games require you to figure out what goes where, not this one, you just shove objects into your invisible inventory and click on the surrounding enviroment until the character picks out the proper piece for the puzzle and shoves it in, hardly puzzling.  And the baby puzzle was enough to make me stop playing, seriously the only Puzzle that I found moderately challenging was challenging for no good reason, was poorly designed, and tedious as hell requiring you to listen to a slowly repeating loop while a baby's cries permeate the game's sounds boring into my soul until I exited as quickly as I could. Its the kind of puzzle I would put up as a prime example of what not to do in a puzzle game.  Everything is pitifully sparse, like they forgot to fill out the game with interesting and exciting details.  No observations provided by the characters of the surrounding enviroment either, the whole atmosphere creates the sensation that the character you are playing is flailing through a boring empty void with the occasional smattering of humor and badly designed puzzles.  Seriously tragic, would requestion a refund if I hadn't Kickstarted it.

People should do themselves a favor and play one of the myriad adventure games that people made for a fraction of the money with many times the quality, check out Machinarium or The Dream Machine (for better quality claymation at a fraction of the budget.)

edit: A few pro's are there, some moderately humorous moments, and creative animation/design every once in a while (seriously some of the design made me smile and made the tragic piece of trash this game is even more upsetting) as well as a really rockingly good intro leading that got me so hyped to get started on the adventure.

reviewText:
I heard about this game being in development several years ago, and it got me very excited. A spiritual successor to Neverhood, the game of my childhood? Hell yeah! Released 20 years later, technology has improved so much in this time, surely it's something to look forward to, right?

Unfortunately that's just not the case. It's inferior to Neverhood in EVERY POSSIBLE WAY.
In Neverhood you are exploring a world. In Armikrog, you're exploring a building...
Did I say exploring? Not really, you're just solving a puzzle after puzzle so you can solve another puzzle.
Armikrog is shorter and smaller, but recycles more assets than Neverhood (barnacles, the slider puzzle, those orange cube creatures, generator, then cart passage in each of the areas - you're basically doing the same thing 3 times)
The Neverhood protagonist doesn't speak, yet somehow manages to display more emotion than both protagonists with voices together...
Somehow Armikrog manages to be inferior even from a technical standpoint, released with many bugs and oversights (after 2 delays for just bugfixing).
Little things like the cursor made from clay, or the amazing Neverhood intro animation are missing as well.

The puzzles (other than the one where you can't get back to the area where you're supposed to find solution - what's up with that?), claymation and music (when it works) are alrigh. That's about it. That's not enough to make me recommend something that had so much potential and wasted it. Buy it only if you've never played Neverhood  AND it's at least 50% off.

reviewText:
I rate Armikrog 2 out of 5. If I had not played The Neverhood, maybe it could be 3, but I cannot stop comparing this game to its very old successor, The Neverhood.

Well, let's face it, if some people make a very unique and fun adventure game in 1996 (The Neverhood), then in 2015, after a very successful crowdfunding campaign, they make a very mediocre successor, with worse storyline, worse soundtrack, dull and repeating puzzles and less funny theme, it is so very disappointing.

This is my first review on Steam, and I’m sorry for my huge negativity, but if you think I’m wrong and you have not played The Neverhood, try it and you’ll understand what I’m talking about.

p.s. A full HD remastered Neverhood would work better for everyone!

reviewText: This certainly was a journey for me. I really enjoyed all the characters. The characters were very expressive, silly and lovable just like previous games (Neverhood and Earthworm Jim). Now I'm more or less going to recommend and defend this game. Puzzle point-and-click adventure games in general are not too long. It's just their make up. Personally, some of the puzzles were fun, and some were confusing (just overlooking some things which made me not understand the puzzle) This game's design is not without flaws of course, but the sheer heart and soul that went into this game is breath-taking!\n\nNow before people get all bent out of shape and start saying Oh it's too short for how long we had to wait
date:
feeling self-entitlted much? Do you have any idea how long stop-motion animation takes and with how small of a team Pencil Test Studios is? Some of those movie sequences could have taken MONTHS to make. The animation quality that Mike Dietz and Ed Schofield put into this game are incredible. Plus you guys are forgetting that like The Neverhood Chronicles, everything was hand-made with clay. Every room you stand in in the game was made with clay. In my opinion though, I'd say for the game's context, it wasn't too short, we had a good prologue, then a conflict, and then an ending. That's the basic principles for a good story, beginning, middle and end. Also you can read up on some of Armikrog's history on the wall if you don't understand the back-story for Armikrog, and thank God it isn't about 15 screens of writing this time!

Now I'll talk a bit about the game's design and a bit about the plot:
In the game Armikrog, you play as two characters side-by-side; TommyNaut and Beak-Beak. TommyNaut is the main protagonist of the story that sort of has a hero-complex and wants to be like his older brothers. Beak-Beak is his best friend and is like a drinking buddy (if you guys have one of those, you'll understand his character). You're stuck in a fortress called Armikrog and have come to realize, a lot of events has happened in this place. I won't spoil the game, so you'll have to see for yourself.

I'm sure you all have come to a cross-road where you are really stuck and have no earthly idea what to do. You've clicked everywhere on the screen, you've visited the hint statue more than once, and still no results. This game does not want to hold your hand while you play it. It wants to make you think and explore. Just like The Neverhood, only Neverhood gave you no auditory hints. If you wanted hints, you'd have to visit your mail box and see what Willie wrote you (Which I might add is at the very beginning of the game, that's a lot of backtracking)! I noticed as well that Pencil Test Stuidos designed the game in mind so that you didn't have to backtrack as much as The Neverhood (thank you)! I will agree that some hints didn't really help me, but after looking around the environment, I eventually figured it out. My advice, every symbol you see, screenshot it, it could come in handy. Some times the hints are too cryptic/ambiguous to understand, just look around the environment  to understand. Some things you may have missed might be right under your nose. Look dilligently through the rooms and use process of elimination when you aren't sure what to do!

So I guess my verdict, the game is definitely worth checking out! But if you want to wait till all the minor and major bugs are fixed, I wouldn't hold it against you. Just remember guys, minor and major bugs are already being resolved by Pencil Test Studios.

reviewText:
This game is sub-mediocre, and I wouldn't recommend the purchase

I saw this on Kickstarter and was interested.  The Neverhood was pretty boring to play, and I wasn't really into it.  However, I was interested in seeing what that original team could do with new game mechanics and graphics, so I wondered how this game would be.

This game is not very good.  The number one thing I was interested in was the story.  The story is thin and boring.  It's not conveyed very well, and it's not that interesting.  And this game is SHORT!  Granted a short cheap game is ok, but I didn't expect it to wrap up so quick.  Also, there's a significant amount of back tracking, and that involves you getting in a trolley system thing and manually going backwards which is really boring.

When I played this game it was also pretty glitchy, though I don't know if they patched that.  Often the sound would unsynch from the game, or I would glitch through a door without solving the puzzle.

The graphics are ok but lame.  They're clay and I expected them to be more ornate, more complex, more beautiful even - I really expected the team to try to push the envelope on 'clay graphics' for lack of a better term.  They're the only ones doing it, so go big!  But they didn't.  They were pretty simple, very Neverhood looking - which I didn't think was that great either.

Finally, a moment of slight spoilers - there is a room with a LONG written story on the wall.  I have no idea what that was about because I couldn't force myself to read it.  However, it's poor form to shoehorn a major story element into a game via a short novel length chunk of text.  Show, don't tell!

So in short, meh graphics, bad story, boring gameplay, overall a let down.

reviewText:
Oh man! So disappointing!

I got The Neverhood free with a computer back in the day and loved it. And then I found it that TenNapel harbers some homophobic views and that sullied it for me somewhat and I was a bit conflicted when I heard Armikrog was to be released.

When it actually came out I decided that not buying a game because of one of the creator's views was the stick but supporting a game that didn't endorse those could be a carrot. That's how I'm rationalising it to myself dammit!

And I started playing and the music was... it lacked the fun quirkiness of the Neverhood, the quirky humour in general was absent, the puzzles are easy with exception of those that require you to find an item (which are just frustrating - especially given the lack of notitification of what's interactable), the game is **way** short, the ending is weird, the bad guy ... actually everyone is basically not-developed, the ending is like 'huh'? I really wanted to like it but I just can't! I wasn't even really hit by the bugs that seem to have plagued a lot of other people...

reviewText:
A Sloppy Unfinished Mess
There isn't even a custom mouse pointer in the game, no options AT ALL for settings, and there is no HUD or GUI at all.  Really really lazy. Boring non-sensical puzzles, boring story, and boring gameplay.  The only thing this has going for it is decent clay graphics.  Not even my nostalgia for The Neverhood and Skullmonkeys (both of which I played when they came out) can carry me through this journey.

Best to wait for a sale if you're interested.  I'd guess it will be on sale rather quickly.

reviewText:
I have to say this game looks great and you can see the hard work that was put in to make it; however, the puzzles are very lacking and miss the point of puzzles. Rather than challenging your mind these puzzles seek to waste your time by having no critical thinking, but instead just bases quite a few of these puzzles on chance or by making the player backtrack in order to see if some action affected the map at all. If you decide to still buy this game i would recommend keeping a camera handy due to the fact that quite a few of the puzzles I've encountered require constructing images with a huge UI in the way of the subject.

In addition to that I have seen a few pieces of the game that scream lazy such as a moving block that is enlarged, but rather than remodeling the block or giving it its own model they took the smaller variant and stretched it. Similar to taking a picture, putting it in microsoft paint, and stretching it vertically thus distorting the quality and making the image seem very blurry. Theres quite a few other bugs and in my opinion i wish the game were delayed slightly more so i could enjoy the feel of the game without the sound cutting out or bugs that required me to restart my client.

This is my first review of a game so i hope this helps some deciding whether or not to buy this.

P.S. Currently I'm on the 4th tower thing and i can't say im too sad that the P. (the baby) has been taken since his puzzle is the worst because of the incredibly slow timer it uses.  I really hope I'm missing something to that challenge since from what I can see there is no way to rush the clock.

reviewText:
Um... Hello! Me - Willy. Me - Willy Trombone...

Or something along those lines.
After reading all the negative reviews comparing Armikrog to The Neverhood I can't help but wonder - when did you guys last play The Neverhood? Because it seems to me that you people are not basing your comparisons on the actual game, but, rather, on your fond memory of the original game. I'm not going to delve into subjective things like quality of atmosphere, immersiveness of story, originality of character design and such. Here is a hard cold fact - The Neverhood and Armikrog are about the same length. Just check the let's plays and see for yourself.

Does Armikrog still have bugs? Yeah. But they are not game-breaking.
Was the voice-acting overhyped? Pretty much. But it does its job of conveying the story and shaping the characters.
Are the puzzles redundant and repetetive? Kind of. But The Neverhood had a memory game and a sliding puzzle. And don't even get me started on that corridor.

Armikrog is still an original, engaging and fun experience. It is not a second Neverhood, as it does some things differently, but, hey, who would want two identical games, right?
